filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive www.blakearchive.org is pleased to announce the publication of the electronic edition of Jerusalem The Emanation of The Giant Albion Copy E. Jerusalem is Blake's masterpiece in illuminated printing, and this copy is his greatest achievement in the medium. Consisting of 100 relief and white-line etchings divided into four chapters, Jerusalem is his longest illuminated book, and its plates are among his largest, approximately 22.5 x 16 cm. Though dated 1804 on its title plate, it was not printed in its entirety until c. 1820. Five complete copies are extant, along with one incomplete colored copy (chapter 1 only) and three complete posthumous copies.
Copy E, the only complete colored copy, is magnificent. All but one plate (51, in black ink) were printed in red-orange on one side of large sheets of J. Whatman 1820 paper, elaborately finished in watercolors, pen and ink, and gold. Each impression is numbered in pen and ink in the top right corner; the first two pages have decorative borders and all the others have one thin line drawn in red-orange ink around the image, setting off each page like a miniature painting. Blake is reputed to have worked on this colored copy well into his final years, though he never found a buyer.
Copy E, from the Paul Mellon Collection of the Yale Center for British Art, joins other copies in the Archive printed and colored in this late style: America a Prophecy Copy O, Europe a Prophecy Copy K, The Marriage of Heaven and Hell Copies G and I, Visions of the Daughters of Albion Copy P, The Book of Thel Copy O, The Book of Urizen Copy G, and Songs of Innocence and of Experience Copies Z and AA. Jerusalem Copy E will eventually be joined by Copy A, whose plates in part 1 are arranged differently, and by Copy I, a posthumous copy, presumably printed by Frederick Tatham, who inherited all of Blake's plates and art works, including Jerusalem Copy E, after Blake's wife Catherine died.
As recipients of our Archive Updates are well aware, we have been working on Jerusalem Copy E for several years. The challenges presented by its scope and difficulty made it an attractive laboratory, in effect, for experiments in editorial method. Many of the adjustments in protocols and processes that arose as solutions to the problems of creating an electronic edition of Jerusalem have already been introduced into other works we have published in the meantime. These include significant alterations in transcription, display, editorial notation, even in line numbering. We also took the opportunity to rescan all of our first generation 4 x 5 inch color transparencies at higher resolution on better equipment, producing digital images of exceptional fidelity and beauty that capture even the texture of the paper. This rescanning and color-correcting process took over two years.
The Archive now contains at least one copy of each of Blake's 19 illuminated books, and in most cases includes copies from each of the printings of the books, for a current total of 49 copies, all fully searchable. In addition to the books, the Archive includes the engraved Illustrations of the Book of Job, generally considered Blake's masterpiece in traditional line engraving and the culmination of his long pictorial engagement with the Book of Job. His first series of 19 watercolors illustrating Job (commissioned c. 1805-06 by his chief patron, Thomas Butts) are available in the Archive in Preview, our mode of presentation that provides all the features of the Archive except Image Search and Inote (our image annotation program). Also in Preview are Blake's illustrations to Milton's "L'Allegro" and "Il Penseroso." Also forthcoming this year are Blake's engraved designs for Robert Blair's The Grave, Edward Young's Night Thoughts, and the Job pencil sketches, along with an illustrated Blake biography and glossary and never-before-reproduced copies of illuminated books.
As always, the William Blake Archive is a free site, imposing no access restrictions and charging no subscription fees. The site is made possible through the continuing support of the Library of Congress, the Institute for Advanced Technology in the Humanities at the University of Virginia, by a major grant from the Preservation and Access Division of the National Endowment for the Humanities, by the University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill, and by the cooperation of the international array of libraries and museums that have generously given us permission to reproduce works from their collections in the Archive.

objdescid.origination: William Blakeauthor, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer, coloristBlake gives his name only as the printer in the imprint, but his authorship is certain.

imprint.pubplace: London The imprint records South Molton Street as the place of publication. This was Blake's residence in London from 1803 to 1821.
imprint.date: 1804The imprint is dated 1804, but Blake probably did not complete the etching of all plates until c. 1820.

objinfo.medium: relief and white-line etching with hand coloring
objinfo.watermark: J Whatman 1820The watermark appears in the leaves bearing Objects 4, 5, 7, 10, 17, 22, 31. 40, 41, 43, 45, 46, 50, 51, 53, 54, 56, 61, 62, 75, 78, 81, 88, 90, 97.
objinfo.etchednumbers: Blake may have etched numbers, top right, on all the plates, but only the following print in Copy E: 5 in white line on Plate 5; 9 in black line on Plate 9; possibly 11 in black line on Plate 10; a fragmentary 3 (of 23?) on Plate 23 in black line; 38 in white line on Plate 38; 9, probably preceded by another numeral, on Plate 50, probably etched in white line but darkly tinted here; 63 in white line on Plate 63; fragments of 65 in black line on Plate 65; 67 in white line on Plate 67; [7?]3 in white line on Plate 73; 75 in black line on Plate 75; [8?]1 in black line on Plate 81; fragments of [8?]8 in white line on Plate 88. The plate numbers given here correspond to the Archive's object numbers in this copy E.

provenance.name: Yale Center for British Art
provenance.note: Probably inherited by Catherine Blake at William Blake's death; Frederick Tatham, who inherited Blake's work upon the death of Catherine Blake in 1831; George Blamire, sold after his death at Christie's, 6 Nov. 1863, lot 213 (£50.8s. to the dealer Daniels); William Fuller-Maitland to his death in 1876; sold anonymously at Christie's, 1 June 1887, lot 255 (166 to the dealer Bernard Quaritch); offered for sale by Quaritch in his 1890 catalogue, *A Hand-List of a Peerless Collection of Books and Manuscripts Exhibited to the Bibliophiles of America*, item 158 ($1500), and in his Feb. 1891 *Rough List* 109, item 97 (£350); acquired from Quaritch c. 1893 by Archibald Sterling; William Sterling by inheritance; sold by Sterling through the dealer Scribner's to Paul Mellon in 1952; given by Mellon to the Yale Center for British art in 1992.

objnote.p: Several lines that appear in the Keynes proof impression (Fitzwilliam Museum) have been deleted from the copperplate. Three words were rubbed off the proof impression itself.
[above the archway] There is a Void, outside of Existence, which if enterd into Englobes itself & becomes a Womb, such was Albions Couch A pleasant Shadow of Repose calld Albions lovely Land

[left and right of the top of the archway] His Sublime & Pathos become Two Rocks fixd in the Earth His Reason his Spectrous Power. covers them above Jerusalem his Emanation is a Stone laying beneath O [Albion behold Pitying] behold the Vision of Albion

In the final line above, three words have been rubbed off the paper of the impression (or deleted "by scratching the copper," Erdman page 809n). Erdman transcribes them conjecturally as "Albion behold pitying" (Erdman page 809n).

[down the right side of the edge of the archway] Half Friendship is the bitterest Enmity said Los As he enterd the Door of Death for Albions sake Inspired The long sufferings of God are not for ever there is a Judgment
[on the left side of the edge of the archway, written backwards:] Every Thing has its Vermin O Spectre of the Sleeping Dead!

illustration.illusobjdesc: A long-haired male figure, seen from behind but facing right, steps with his right foot across the threshold of an arched entryway whose interior is dark. The disappearance of his right foot across the threshold may imply that he is stepping down onto a stairway, perhaps, that leads to a crypt. With left arm bent upward and fingers slightly spread, he appears to push and peer through the heavy door, only slightly ajar, opening inward on the right. The globed lantern in the figure's right hand and the sandal on his visible foot suggest he is Los, the watchman of the text, who, "Putting on his golden sandals" (Plate 83, line 77), carries a "red Globe of fire" (Plate 85, line 20) in his hand as he sings his Watch Song (Plates 85-86). Los's sandals somewhat incongruously complete the rest of his attire: a long-sleeved, belted tunic or coat and wide-brimmed hat. The brightness of the round object that he holds illuminates most of the design, casting its beams of light across the edges of the portal and the wall into which it is built. Inscriptions, later expurgated, on and above the archway in a proof copy identify the structure framing Los as a sepulchral descent into Albion: "Half friendship is the bitterest Enmity said Los / As he enterd the Door of Death for Albions sake Inspired" (Erdman page 144).

component.illusobjdesc: A long-haired male figure, seen from behind but facing right, steps with his right foot across the threshold of an arched entryway. His prominent left foot shows he wears sandals with discernible straps around the calf, although the bands between his knees and ankles also suggest breeches; he also wears a long-sleeved, cinched coat or tunic whose bottom folds and hem swirl to the left and back, and a wide-brimmed hat. With left arm bent upward, fingers slightly spread, and palm facing away from the viewer, he appears to push and peer through a heavy door, which is slightly ajar. The figure's right arm is at his side; iin his hand he clasps a circular, radiating object, whose transparency makes it appear as though his fingers simply intersect with the beams of light. The globular object and the sandals on his feet suggest the figure is Los, the watchman of the text, who, "Putting on his golden sandals" (Plate 83, line 77), carries a "red Globe of fire" (Plate 85, line 20) in his hand as he sings his Watch Song (Plates 85-86).

In his right hand, Los clasps a circular, radiating object made of a spiral line and radiating beams of light—perhaps a lantern, even a sun-lantern—whose transparency makes it appear as though his fingers simply intersect with the beams of light. The globular object and the sandals on the male's feet suggest the figure is Los, the watchman of the text, who, "Putting on his golden sandals" (Plate 83, line 77), carries a "red Globe of fire" (Plate 85, line 20) in his hand. The disk illuminates most of the design, casting its rays across the edges of the portal and the wall into which it is built.

Los steps across the threshold or doorstep of a Gothic entryway whose interior, of which the viewer catches only a glimpse, is dark, despite the intensity of the rays emitting from Los's lantern. The disappearance of his right foot across the threshold may imply that he is stepping down onto a stairway, perhaps, that leads to a crypt. The door is slightly ajar, opening inward on the right, and built into what in other copies is clearly a stone or brick wall, though its masonry in Copy E is largely concealed by the beams of light from the radiating disk. Inscriptions, later expurgated, on and above the archway in a proof copy identify the architecture framing Los as a sepulchral descent into Albion: "Half friendship is the bitterest Enmity said Los / As he enterd the Door of Death for Albions sake Inspired" (Erdman page 144).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The border depicts motifs that anticipate subsequent plates: chains hang down the left and right margins, and in the lower corners are spiky-leafed/bat-winged shapes that obscure the distinction between flora and fauna. Centered at bottom, beneath Los's prominent left foot, is a branch of thorns.

component.illusobjdesc: Chains hang down the left and right margins of the border, anticipating subsequent plates, such as Plate 65. The bottom links of both chains have a modified shape, suggesting shackles, perhaps.

desc.objtitle: Jerusalem The Emanation of The Giant Albion, Object 2 (Bentley 2, Erdman 2, Keynes 2)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text of the title, emblazoned across a cloudy sky with "Jerusalem" in a burst of red light, is surrounded by five figures with body-length wings and other features that inevitably suggest angels but also birds and flying insects. They may be among the fairies mentioned in the first paragraph of "To the Public" (Plate 3). Markings on the wings of the three figures at the top, bottom, and lower right represent astronomical objects. Clockwise from the top are a gowned, moth-like female flying in a horizontal position; a gowned female flying in a standing position with her face hidden in her hands, as if mourning; a nude female lying face up with her eyes closed— sleeping or dead—her long hair stretched out above her head, and her arms raised vertically; above her, sitting or squatting, a gowned female with her head resting on her hand, as if mourning; and a figure with less determinate features, though probably a gowned female, flying in a near-vertical position. Perhaps all five of the figures around the title are fairies acting in parallel to the main action of the poem. Or perhaps the figure on the bottom is actually Jerusalem ("Wingd with Six Wings" [Plate 86, line 2] according to Los) sleeping the Sleep of Ulro while flanked by two mourning women. The colors of the background, especially along the bottom and right sides of the plate, may suggest a rainbow, sunset, or sunrise in a cloudy sky—or light breaking in on darkness—with an area of darkness above the figures and blue sky in the central areas. An assortment of human and animal figures appears among the letters of the title, and a few of the letters have vegetative extensions.

component.illusobjdesc: The text of the title is surrounded by five figures with body-length wings and other features that inevitably suggest angels but also birds and flying insects. They may be among the fairies mentioned in the first paragraph of "To the Public" (Plate 3). At the top above "Jerusalem" is a gowned female flying in a horizontal position facing left with her visible left arm wrapped around her head. She is wearing a shoe on her one visible foot. Her wings, which seem to extend her otherwise long hair, have a rounded shape that resemble a moth's or dragonfly's. Their top edges are marked by indistinct shapes that may be intended as stars or dots in the wings nearest the viewer. Like the other figures, she appears to be wearing a headpiece or petal-like hat wrapped around her head with her hair visible in front and flowing out behind.

The text of the title is surrounded by five figures with body-length wings and other features that inevitably suggest angels but also birds and flying insects. They may be among the fairies mentioned in the first paragraph of "To the Public" (Plate 3). Along the right side is a gowned female standing or floating in a vertical position facing left with her face buried in her hands, as if mourning over the figure lying across the bottom of the plate. The mourning figure's face is obscured by a kind of hat whose points resemble flower petals, perhaps a sunflower's, topped with what may be ribbon or antennae (there is a similar hat on the figure directly opposite). The lower part of her body tapers to a point, like the body of a butterfly. Her wings, which seem to replace or extend her otherwise long hair (sweeping upward), have a shape that may be butterfly-like, though the thickness of their top edges suggests the wings of a bird or angel. The bottom set of wings is marked by indistinct shapes that are probably intended as stars; the top set is marked by a crescent moon.

The text of the title is surrounded by five figures with body-length wings and other features that inevitably suggest angels but also birds and flying insects. They may be among the fairies mentioned in the first paragraph of "To the Public" (Plate 3). Across the bottom of the plate a nude female with her eyes closed lies supine, breasts and genitals exposed, her arms raised vertically, and her long hair extended between her wings above her head. Her right palm is up, and she wears a bracelet on her right wrist. Her feet are vegetating, and her pubic area is crisscrossed in a way that suggests vegetative filaments. Her wings are elaborately veined or ribbed, fringed with points, and divided into three sets. The lower set is marked with stars, separated into zones by lines that may suggest the veins of a leaf. The middle set is marked by two crescent moons in opposing phases. The upper set is marked by two suns or planets. She is probably Jerusalem ("Wingd with Six Wings" [Plate 86, line 2], according to Los) in the Sleep of Ulro—or perhaps a fairy in a parallel state. In the context of the design to the left of the verse stanza on the next plate (3), she may also be a chrysalis.

The text of the title is surrounded by five figures with body-length wings and other features that inevitably suggest angels but also birds and flying insects. They may be among the fairies mentioned in the first paragraph of "To the Public" (Plate 3). On the left, beside "The Giant Albion," a gowned female squats or sits on the extension of the “A” of “Albion,” just above the supine figure. As if to suggest that she, like the figure opposite her, is mourning over the female below, her cheek rests on her left hand; she holds her right arm bent with the palm forward. Though her wings resemble those of the other two figures in the lower half of the plate, the color and configuration of hers may be more bat-like than theirs, and hers lack astronomical markings. Her long hair extends up and back into her wings, and her face is fringed with a pointed cap or hat—perhaps the points of sunflower petals or batwings on either side of her face—like the one that hides the face of the figure opposite her. She is dressed in the most detailed clothing of any figure on the plate. Her gown ends in spiky sleeves shaped like batwings, as does her collar. There are also spots near the hem of her layered skirt, or what may be an apron, which likewise ends in a spiky or scalloped pattern. She appears to be wearing a bracelet on her left wrist and a band around her upper right arm.

The text of the title is surrounded by five figures with body-length wings and other features that inevitably suggest angels but also birds and flying insects. They may be among the fairies mentioned in the first paragraph of "To the Public" (Plate 3). At top left is a forward-facing flying figure with indistinct features. In the context of the rest of the design, the figure is probably female. She may be wearing a hat resembling a sunflower, like two other figures on this plate, with antennae rising from it. Insofar as her arms are distinguishable, they are raised vertically.

The colors of the background, especially along the bottom and right sides of the plate, may suggest a rainbow, sunset, or sunrise in a cloudy sky—or light breaking in on darkness—with an area of darkness above the figures and blue sky in the central areas.
The title is emblazoned across a cloudy sky; "Jerusalem" is in a burst of red light.

Between "The" and "Giant" hovers a tiny human being, with its arms extended horizontally and its right leg extended backward. Right of the initial "E" of "Emanation" is another hovering figure, with its arms raised at 135 degrees. A third figure sits, facing away from the viewer, on a vine-like scroll between the "a" and "n" of "Giant."

Three flying insects of indeterminate type fly in the "G" and above the "a" and "n" of "Giant"—perhaps a fly on the left and a butterfly or moth on the right. The insect in the center has spiky wings.
Below the end of "Jerusalem" flies an eagle-like bird. Two other birds, very slight, fly above the "b" and, slight indeed, above the "on" of "Albion."

Several letters of the title have decorative vine-like extensions. There is a butterfly or insect between the “r” and “u” of “Jerusalem” and a fairy or human being within the “E” of “Emanation.” "Giant" is heavily ornamented with indistinct forms, as is "Albion."

desc.objtitle: To the Public, Object 3 (Bentley 3, Erdman 3, Keynes 3)

objnote.p: On this plate Blake made numerous deletions that leave gaps in the sense and syntax. At that time he may also have added the white-line inscriptions, "SHEEP" and "GOATS", at the top corners, though technically he could have inscribed those earlier. Erdman reads the deletions as follows (Erdman pages 145, 809n). Bentley generally accepts Erdman's readings but offers them less confidently (Bentley pages 419-20nn1-13) and reserves special doubts for a few, as noted below.
lines 6-7: "the [love] and [friendship] of those with whom to be connected, is to be [blessed]."

lines 9ff.: "The Enthusiasm of the following Poem, the Author hopes [no Reader will think presumptuousness or arroganc when he is reminded that the Ancients acknowledge their love to their Deities, to the full as Enthusiastically as I have who Acknowledge mine for my Saviour and Lord, for they were wholly absorb'd in their Gods.] I also hope the Reader will be with me, wholly One in Jesus our Lord, who is the God [of Fire] and Lord [of Love] to whom the Ancients look'd and saw his day afar off, with trembling & amazement." ("arroganc": i.e., "arrogance.") Bentley is uncertain about the following words of Erdman's transcription: "no Reader . . . presumptuousness . . . their love . . . Writing, . . . who Acknowledge . . . Saviour and Lord . . . were . . . Gods . . . of Fire . . . of Love" (Bentley pages 419nn5-7).
lines 20-21: "Therefore [Dear] Reader, [forgive] what you do not approve, & [love] me for this energetic exertion of my talent."
lines 22-23: "Reader! [lover] of books! [lover] of heaven. / And of that God from whom [all books are given,]"

line 35ff.: " . . . Digestion or Sleep. [Greek text to note the last words of Jesus.]" (Matthew 28.18, the first words of Jesus's final address to his disciples: "All power is given unto me in heaven and in earth"). Bentley expresses uncertainty about Erdman's transcription (Bentley 420n).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Flying forms amidst sky and clouds dominate the interlinear designs. Midway down the plate on the left, a nude female is one of three or four winged creatures flanking the verse portion of the text (lines 22-33). Her legs are together, terminating in roots or other vegetable matter rather than feet. Bat- or flame-like wings—or spiky leaves suggesting a vegetative state—substitute for arms. Across the way from her, to the right of the poem, are three more ambiguous shapes, the topmost of which (to the right of and above "heaven" in line 22) appears more bird-like than human. The lower figure, following "desire" in line 27, is a miniature version, its features less defined, of the female on the left side of the plate, and the middle motif is an amorphous shape whose status, whether animal or vegetable, is difficult to determine. Various other small-scale vegetative motifs, for the most part extensions of letters, adorn the text here and there, e.g., the serpentine flourish extending left of the "T" of "The" in line 9 and the single-looped vine growing from the "s" of "parts" near the bottom of the plate (line 46). The text appears to be inscribed on cloud. In the upper corners of the plate the words "SHEEP" (left) and "GOATS" (right) are integrated into the design, as though written on fiery clouds displacing an otherwise cloudy blue sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Midway down the plate on the left, a nude female is one of three or four winged creatures flanking the verse portion of the text (lines 22-33). Her legs are together, terminating in a root-like or flame-like rather than feet. Bat-like wings—or spiky leaves suggesting a vegetative state—substitute for arms. The figure either reclines in a semi-supine position or flies against the backdrop of sky and clouds, facing forward and right. She faces forward and right.

Right of the verse portion of the text (lines 22-33) are three ambiguous shapes, the topmost of which (just above "heaven" in line 22) appears, unlike its winged companion below, more bird-like than human, perhaps flying down and left against a background of sky and clouds.

Following "desire" in line 27 flies a miniature version, its features less defined, of the female on the left side of the plate: a tiny bat- or flame-winged figure, or else a figure vegetating into a spiky-leafed form. Directly above it is an amorphous motif whose status, whether animal or vegetable, is difficult to determine; though resembling a detached bit of root-tail or bat-wing from one of its neighbors, it may instead be another complete but sketchy figure.

Various small-scale vegetative motifs, for the most part extensions of letters, adorn the text here and there, e.g., the serpentine flourish extending left of the "T" of "The" in line 9 and the single-looped vine growing from the "s" of "parts" near the bottom of the plate (line 46). Leafy or root-like ascenders and descenders are also prevalent: note the "W," for example, of "When" in line 36; or the "d" of "and" at the end of line 47.

The text of the plate looks to be inscribed on clouds; blue sky backs the text and designs, giving way to fiery patches in the upper corners, on which are written the words "SHEEP" (left) and "GOATS" (right). The fiery patches may suggest either sunrise or sunset. The dark area across the bottom of the plate suggests a strip of earth.
Fiery patches of sky or clouds in the upper corners of the plate are inscribed with the words "SHEEP" (left) and "GOATS" (right).

from the modern bondage of Rhyming; to be a necessary
and indispensible part of Verse. But I soon found that
in the mouth of a true Orator such monotony was not
only awkward, but as much a bondage as rhyme itself.
I therefore have produced a variety in every line. both
of cadences & number of syllables. Every word and
every letter is studied and put into its fit place: the
terrific numbers are reserved for the terrific parts
the mild & gentle, for the mild & gentle parts. and
the prosaic, for inferior parts; all are necessary to
each other. Poetry Fetter'd. Fetters the Human Race.
Nations are Destroy'd, or Flourish, in proportion as Their
Poetry Painting and Music, are Destroy'd or Flourish! The
Primeval State of Man, was Wisdom, Art, and Science.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Against a cloudy night sky with crescent moon and three stars, a robed or gowned and hooded sibyl sits between two nude males and reaches out toward their heads. She grips the back of the head of the male seated (half-kneeling) to the right. The male seated to the left leans sharply away from the sibyl, reclining against a rock and raising his hands in a praying position. The three sit on a grassy peninsula or island— perhaps a representation of Britain—that drops off sharply, cliff- like, on the right, where water is visible. To the left of this group, curving around the "J" of "Jerusalem," is a line of four hovering females. Below the uppermost of these—who reaches down with one hand while pointing right with the other toward the Greek words for "Jesus only" that are inscribed in the sky above the crescent moon—two of the other females reach upward toward her. Only the upper body of the fourth female is visible just above the rock below the "J." The word "Jerusalem" is inscribed across the design in a cloud.

component.illusobjdesc: Facing forward a robed or gowned and hooded sibyl squats – or sits with knees drawn up – between two nude males. She reaches out toward them with both arms horizontal, palms nearly vertical. Her left hand grips the back of the head of the figure to the right. Both of her feet are visible under the hem of her gown.

Facing right with his head up, a short-haired nude male half sits, half squats on the ground to the right of a sibyl who grips the back of his head. His left leg is drawn up. Both hands are on the ground, his right arm forward between his legs, his left arm behind him, supporting his weight.

With his back to the viewer and facing left, a short- haired nude male sits to the left of a sibyl who reaches out as if to grip the back of his head as she grips the head of the figure to her right. This male, however, leans sharply left, reclining on the left side of his upper body on a rock, looking toward the three hovering women. His hands are raised together in a praying or supplicating position. His legs are not visible except for his upper right thigh.

Just above the rock where a nude male raises his hands in a praying position, a long-haired nude female hovers(?), her arms horizontal, leaning and reaching to the left in a line of other hovering nude figures. Conceivably she is lying supine on the ground. She faces away from the viewer; only the top of her body is visible. Her left hand may touch the adjacent figure's leg.

Left of the lower part of the "J" of "Jerusalem," a nude female(?), facing away, floats in a line of other female figures. Her left leg is extended backward, her body twisted clockwise, and her arms raised vertically, reaching toward the uppermost female. She may be wearing some kind of headgear, perhaps a scarf or even a hood. The figure's right hand may be touching the topmost figure's feet.
To the left of the "J" of "Jerusalem," a nude female hovers between two others. Her arms are raised vertically. She is reaching and looking toward the uppermost female, whose arm she may be holding.

At top left floats a nude female, her body twisted clockwise to look back and down at the figures below her. Her hair is short or pulled back in a bun. With her right arm she reaches down toward the figures below, while with her left arm she points right, perhaps at the Greek words for "Jesus only" inscribed above a crescent moon. Her right foot touches the arm of a subjacent figure.

Several figures sit on a grassy island or peninsula; water, perhaps the sea, is visible on the right, at the bottom of a steep drop, perhaps intended for cliffs. There is a rock or hillock on the left. Altogether this may be a representation of Britain itself. If so, the cliffs may be those of Dover, and the net-like marginal designs below may be analogous to the net-like cracks(?) on the cliffs of Dover as depicted on Plate 50. The area outlined on which the text is inscribed would in that case represent the cliff face.
The scene is set against a dark and cloudy night sky beneath a large crescent moon and three prominent stars.

The word "Jerusalem" is inscribed across the design in a cloud. In the sky above the crescent moon are Greek words for "Jesus only." "Chap: 1" is inscribed on the surface of the rock or hill to the left of the three seated figures.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Root-like or vine-like tendrils extend down the left margin, and a net or web extends into the spaces of the right margin from the large design at the top of the plate. The net-like structures may, however, be analogous to similar structures—perhaps representing a network of cracks—seen on the cliffs of Dover in plate 50. If so, the area outlined around the text represents the cliff face itself, extended from the grassy top surface above. A few letters have decorative extensions, such as the initial "T" of line 7.

texthead.l: Movos o IesousThe transliterated Greek words for "Jesus Only".

lg.l: Chap: 1
Of the Sleep of Ulro! and of the passage through
Eternal Death! and of the awaking to Eternal Life
This theme calls me in sleep night after night, & ev'ry morn
Awakes me at sun-rise, then I see the Saviour over me
Spreading his beams of love, & dictating the words of this mild song.
Awake! awake O sleeper of the land of shadows, wake! expand!
I am in you and you in me, mutual in love divine:
Fibres of love from man to man thro Albions pleasant land.
In all the dark Atlantic vale down from the hills of Surrey
A black water accumulates, return Albion! return!
Thy brethren call thee. and thy fathers, and thy sons,
Thy nurses and thy mothers, thy sisters and thy daughters
Weep at thy souls disease, and the Divine Vision is darkend:
Thy Emanation that was wont to play before thy face,
Beaming forth with her daughters into the Divine bosom."Where!" was incompletely deleted on the copperplate from the end of this line.
Where hast thou hidden thy Emanation lovely Jerusalem
From the vision and fruition of the Holy-one?
I am not a God afar off, I am a brother and friend;
Within your bosoms I reside, and you reside in me:
Lo! we are One; forgiving all Evil; Not seeking recompense!
Ye are my members O ye sleepers of Beulah. land of shades!
But the perturbed Man away turns down the valleys dark;

l.note: After line 26, a line was deleted on the copperplate. Erdman reads it as "Saying. We are not One: we are Many, thou most simulative" (Erdman page 146).

lg.l: Phantom of the over heated brain! shadow of immortality!
Seeking to keep my soul a victim to thy Love! which binds
Man the enemy of man into deceitful friendships;
Jerusalem is not! her daughters are indefinite;
By demonstration, man alone can live, and not by faith.
My mountains are my own, and I will keep them to myself:
The Malvern and the Cheviot, the Wolds Plinlimmon & Snowdon
Are mine. here will I build my Laws of Moral Virtue:
Humanity shall be no more: but war & princedom & victory!
So spoke Albion in jealous fears, hiding his Emanation
Upon the Thames and Medway, rivers of Beulah: dissembling
His jealousy before the throne divine, darkening. cold!

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design elements are concentrated in the right margin, where five female forms in various postures ornament the plate, all of whom, with the exception of the second figure from the bottom, gaze upward. Flames engulfing the lowermost figure gradually dissipate as they move up the margin, giving way to ropy vines. Blue wash suggesting sky backs the topmost figures. Continuing the flame motif of the design, an orange-red palette provides a backdrop to most of the text.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude female, engulfed by flames, appears in the bottom right margin of the plate. With right leg crossed over left and hands (presumably) folded together (perhaps in prayer, though only the left hand is visible), she gazes upward. She may have long hair.

Midway down the plate in the right margin, two gowned, long-haired females kneel, the figure in the forefront with head down, her companion with head up. The face of the former is obscured by her long hair, which resembles the nearby flames. Hunched over as though in mourning(?), she seems to rest her head on her right hand, and her right foot shows from beneath or through her gown, as does that of her companion. The second female gazes up with hands clasped together as if praying or supplicating.

To the right of the second stanza, a nude female hovers with legs together, arms raised at 135 degrees, and palms up. Like her companions directly above and below her, she gazes upward. Her arched torso is twisted counterclockwise from her lower body. Flames lick the spaces behind her at her feet and below her outstretched left arm.

Hovering in the upper right corner of the plate, beside the first stanza, a female figure gazes upward, her hands together as though in prayer. Though she appears to be nude, her feet are obscured and drawn to a point—perhaps she wears a transparent gown.

A long, narrow tongue of fire streaks across the bottom of the plate; its flames expand into the right margin, engulfing the lowermost figure and gradually dissipating as they move up the margin, replaced by or transformed into ropy vines, though still prominent where they lick the spaces behind the second figure from the top. An orange-red palette, providing a backdrop to the text, continues the fire motif.

Fire engulfs the figure in the bottom right corner and gradually dissipates as it moves up the margin, replaced by or transformed into ropy vines. Fire or a thick growth of (flame-like?) vine(?) continues across the top and bottom of the plate.
Blue wash suggesting sky backs the topmost figures of the vertically oriented design and extends halfway down the right margin.

l.note: Blake may have etched numbers, top right, on all the plates, but only a small percentage of them printed in Copy E. Here, a "5" in white line is partially visible just below the pen-and-ink numeral "5" of line 1.

lg.l: The banks of the Thames are clouded! the ancient porches of Albion are
Darken'd! they are drawn thro' unbounded space, scatter'd upon
The Void in incohererent despair! Cambridge & Oxford & London."incohererent": i.e., "incoherent".
Are driven among the starry Wheels. rent away and dissipated,
In Chasms & Abysses of sorrow, enlarg'd without dimension, terrible
Albions mountains run with blood. the cries of war & of tumult
Resound into the unbounded night, every Human perfection
Of mountain & river & city. are small & wither'd & darken'd
Cam is a little stream! Ely is almost swallowd up!
Lincoln & Norwich stand trembling on the brink of Udan-Adan!
Wales and Scotland shrink themselves to the west and to the north!
Mourning for fear of the warriors in the Vale of Entuthon-Benython
Jerusalem is scatterd abroad like a cloud of smoke thro' non-entity:
Moab & Ammon & Amalek & Canaan & Egypt & Aram
Recieve her little-ones for sacrifices and the delights of cruelty
Trembling I sit day and night, my friends are astonish'd at me
Yet they forgive my nderings, I rest not from my great task!In Copy E, the letters "wa" in "wanderings" did not print.
To open the Eternal Worlds, to open the immortal Eyes
Of Man inwards into the Worlds of Thought: into Eternity
Ever expanding in the Bosom of God, the Human Imagination
O Saviour pour upon me thy Spirit of meekness & love:
Annihilate the Selfhood in me, be thou all my life!
Guide thou my hand which trembles exceedingly upon the rock of ages,
While I write of the building of Golgonooza. & of the terrors of Entuthon:
Of Hand & Hyle & Coban. of Kwantok. Peachey. Brereton. Slayd & Hutton:
Of the terrible sons & daughters of Albion. and their Generations.
Scofield: Kox. Kotope and Bowen, revolve most mightily upon
The Furnace of Los: before the eastern gate bending their fury.
They war, to destroy the Furnaces, to desolate Golgonooza:
And to devour the Sleeping Humanity of Albion in rage & hunger.
They revolve into the Furnaces Southward & are driven forth Northward
Divided into Male and Female forms time after time.
From these Twelve all the Families of England spread abroad.
The Male is a Furnace of beryll; the Female is a golden Loom;
I behold them and their rushing fires overwhelm my Soul;
In Londons darkness; and my tears fall day and night,
Upon the Emanations of Albions Sons! the Daughters of Albion
Names anciently rememberd, but now contemn'd as fictions:
Although in every bosom they controll our Vegetative powers.
These are united into Tirzah and her Sisters. on Mount Gilead.
Cambel & Gwendolen & Conwenna & Cordella & Ignoge.
And these united into Rahab in the Covering Cherub on Euphrates
Gwiniverra & Gwinefred. & Gonorill & Sabrina beautiful.
Estrild, Mehetabel & Ragan, lovely Daughters of Albion.
They are the beautiful Emanations of the Twelve Sons of Albion
The Starry Wheels revolv'd heavily over the Furnaces;
Drawing Jerusalem in anguish of maternal love,
Eastward a pillar of a cloud with Vala upon the mountains
Howling in pain. redounding from the arms of Beulahs Daughters,
Out from the Furnaces of Los above the head of Los.
A pillar of smoke writhing afar into Non-Entity, redounding
Till the cloud reaches afar outstretch'd among the Starry Wheels
Which revolve heavily in the mighty Void above the Furnaces
O what avail the loves & tears of Beulahs lovely Daughters
They hold the Immortal Form in gentle bands & tender tears
But all within is open'd into the deeps of Entuthon Benython
A dark and unknown night. indefinite. unmeasurable. without end.
Abstract Philosophy warring in enmity against Imagination
Which is the Divine Body of the Lord Jesus. blessed for ever).The parenthesis that closes at the end of this line should probably open at the beginning of the line.
And there Jerusalem wanders with Vala upon the mountains.
Attracted by the revolutions of those Wheels the Cloud of smoke:
Immense. and Jerusalem & Vala weeping in the Cloud
Wander away into the Chaotic Void, lamenting with her Shadow
Among the Daughters of Albion, among the Starry Wheels:
Lamenting for her children, for the sons & daughters of Albion
Los heard her lamentations in the deeps afar! his tears fall
Incessant before the Furnaces, and his Emanation divided in pain.
Eastward toward the Starry Wheels. But Westward a black Horror.In Copy E, the "t" in "Starry" printed very faintly, and the letters "rror" in "Horror" are almost illegible.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Los appears as a blacksmith in his shop, with large tongs (left), hammer and anvil (between his legs), bellows (behind him to the right), and flaming, smoking forge (left). Los, a nude male with short, curly hair, holds his hammer as he straddles an anvil that sits on the stone floor in the center of the design. He looks up toward his spectre, a dark, bat-winged figure who hovers in the flames above. Only the head, arms, upper back, and wings of this figure are visible: he flies in a prone position with the top and rear of his head toward the viewer. His head appears to be bald. He looks straight down at Los while holding his hands to his ears. The links of a massive chain extend from the floor to the bottom of the bellows and from the top of the bellows under the wing of the spectre.

component.illusobjdesc: Los, a nude male with short, curly hair, appears as a blacksmith at his forge. He holds his (phallic) hammer between his legs, his right hand resting on the head below, his left up to rest on the end of the handle. He straddles an anvil with his right leg drawn up, his right foot resting on the lower step of the anvil, and his left leg extended back and to the side. Seen in profile facing left, he raises his head to look up toward the spectre who hovers directly overhead.

A dark, bat-winged spectre hovers in the flames directly above Los. His vast, spiky wings are sectioned by ribs that extend from shoulder to wingtip. Only the head, arms, upper back, and wings of the spectre are visible: he hovers or flies in a prone position with the top and rear of his head toward the viewer. His head appears to be bald. Holding his hands to his ears, he looks straight down at Los.

Very large bellows, partly visible, rest on the forge behind Los to the right, echoing the bat-like wing of the spectre above. The links of a massive chain, presumably used to operate the bellows, extend from the floor to the bottom of the bellows and from the top of the bellows under the wing of the spectre.
The fire in the forge sends out flames and billowing smoke. The smoke extends into the upper reaches of the plate.
Very large tongs rest to the left of Los in front of the forge. Their pivot end rests against an invisible surface; the closed ends of their arms rest on the floor.
The floor of Los's forge appears to be made of stones, and there is a rock of some sort on the floor between the anvil and his left foot. The anvil and forge itself appear to be made of stone.
Los straddles a stone(?) anvil that consists of a broader base and a narrower top section.
To the left of Los is a blacksmith's forge.

lg.l: His Spectre driv'n by the Starry Wheels of Albions sons. black and
Opake divided from his back; he labours and he mourns!
For as his Emanation divided, his Spectre also divided
In terror of those starry wheels: and the Spectre stood over Los
Howling in pain: a blackning Shadow. blackning dark & opake
Cursing the terrible Los: bitterly cursing him for his friendship
To Albion. suggesting murderous thoughts against Albion.
Los rag'd and stamp'd the earth in his might & terrible wrath!
He stood and stampd the earth! then he threw down his hammer in rage &
In fury; then he sat down and wept, terrified! Then arose
And chaunted his song, labouring with the tongs and hammer:
But still the Spectre divided, and still his pain increas'd!
In pain the Spectre divided! in pain of hunger and thirst:
To devour Los's Human Perfection, but when he saw that Los

illustration.illusobjdesc: As with Plate 5, the interlinear designs are concentrated in the right margin, where vigorous, leafy vegetation or flames and smoke swirl around three figures in sundry positions, two of whom, at opposite ends, plunge into its terminal loops and spirals; the central male figure, by contrast, stands in contrapposto.

component.illusobjdesc: Near the bottom of the right margin, a nude male, seen from behind, descends head first, arms raised vertically and hands and legs together, into spirals of smoke or vegetative loops.

Midway down the right margin of the plate, a nude male, surrounded by vigorous, leafy vegetation or smoke curls, stands in contrapposto. He faces right, his left arm bent upward with palm out and fingers spread, his right arm at his side.
A long-haired, nude female ascends through smoke curls or leafy spirals near the top right margin of the plate. With pointed finger, she extends her only visible arm vertically over her head.

Smoke curls and/or vigorous, leafy vegetation, with terminal spirals at top and bottom, swirl around three figures in the right margin of the plate. The yellow and green washes suggest verdure, but images of fire, smoke, forge, and furnace in the text, as well as a visual continuity with the smoke and fire motifs on Plates 5 and 6, reinforce the flame-like characteristics of the design.

lg.l: Was living: panting like a frighted wolf. and howling
He stood over the Immortal. in the solitude and darkness:
Upon the darkning Thames, across the whole Island westward.
A horrible Shadow of Death, among the Furnaces; beneath
The pillar of folding smoke; and he sought by other means.
To lure Los: by tears, by arguments of science & by terrors:
Terrors in every Nerve, by spasms & extended pains:
While Los answer'd unterrified to the opake blackening Fiend
And thus the Spectre spoke; Wilt thou still go on to destruction?
Till thy life is all taken away by this deceitful Friendship?
He drinks thee up like water! like wine he pours thee
Into his tuns: thy Daughters are trodden in his vintage
He makes thy Sons the trampling of his bulls, they are plow'd.
And harrowd for his profit, lo! thy stolen Emanation
Is his garden of pleasure! all the Spectres of his Sons mock thee
Look how they scorn thy once admired palaces; now in ruins
Because of Albion! because of deceit and friendship! For Lo !
Hand has peopled Babel & Nineveh: Hyle. Ashur & Aram;
Cobans son is Nimrod: his son Cush is adjoind to Aram.
By the Daughter of Babel, in a woven mantle of pestilence & war,
They put forth their spectrous cloudy sails; which drive their immense
Constellations over the deadly deeps of indefinite Udan-Adan
Kox is the Father of Shem & Ham & Japheth. he is the Noah
Of the Flood of Udan-Adan. Hutn is the Father of the Seven
From Enoch to Adam; Schofield is Adam who was New-
Created in Edom. I saw it indignant, & thou art not moved!
This has divided thee in sunder! and wilt thou still forgive?
O! thou seest not what I see! what is done in the Furnaces.
Listen I will tell thee what is done in moments to thee unknown:
Luvah was cast into the Furnaces of affliction and sealed.
And Vala fed in cruel delight, the Furnaces with fire:
Stern Urizen beheld; urgd by necessity to keep
The evil day afar. and if perchance with iron power
He might avert his own despair: in woe & fear he saw
Vala incircle round the Furnaces where Luvah was clos'd:
With joy she heard his howlings, & forgot he was her Luvah.
With whom she liv'd in bliss in times of innocence & youth!
Vala comes from the Furnace in a cloud. but wretched Luvah
Is howling in the Furnaces, in flames among Albions Spectres.
To prepare the Spectre of Albion to reign over thee O Los.
Forming the Spectres of Albion according to his rage:
To prepare the Spectre sons of Adam, who is Scofield: the Ninth
Of Albions sons. & the father of all his brethren in the Shadowy
Generation. Cambel & Gwendolen wove webs of war & of
Religion, to involve all Albions sons, and when they had
Involv'd Eight; their webs roll'd outwards into darkness
And Scofield the Ninth remaind on the outside of the Eight
And Kox. Kotope, & Bowen, One in him, a Fourfold Wonder
Involv'd the Eight—Such are the Generations of the Giant Albion.
To separate a Law of Sin. to punish thee in thy members.
Los answer'd, Altho' I know not this! I know far worse than this:
I know that Albion hath divided me. and that thou O my Spectre.
Hast just cause to be irritated: but look stedfastly upon me:
Comfort thyself in my strength the time will arrive,
When all Albions injuries shall cease, and when we shall
Embrace him tenfold bright. rising from his tomb in immortality.
They have divided themselves by Wrath. they must be united by
Pity: let us therefore take example & warning O my Spectre,
O that I could abstain from wrath! O that the Lamb
Of God would look upon me and pity me in my fury.
In anguish of regeneration! in terrors of self annihilation:
Pity must join together those whom wrath has torn in sunder.
And the Religion of Generation which was meant for the destruction
Of Jerusalem, become her covering. till the time of the End.

O holy Generation! of regeneration!In the last half of the line, "Image" does not print at all clearly: "[Image] of regeneration". The word is legible in Copies A and posthumous Copy I and clearly legible in Copies B and D (because of retouching on these two impressions, according to Erdman page 809n).
O point of mutual forgiveness between Enemies!
Birthplace of the Lamb of God incomprehensible!
The Dead despise & scorn thee, & cast thee out as accursed:
Seeing the Lamb of God in thy gardens & thy palaces:
Where they desire to place the Abomination of Desolation.
Hand sits before his furnace: scorn of others & furious pride:
Freeze round him to bars of steel & to iron rocks beneath
His feet: indignant self-righteousness like whirlwinds of the north:

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a night sky with prominent clouds and three stars, a long-haired, nude female is harnessed to a spherical moon as if to a chariot. Light from below creates a crescent around the periphery of the sphere. Holding her arms bent up at the elbows before her, she looks back toward the sphere as she pulls it to the left across a cloud. She walks left on the surface of the cloud with the moon floating behind her. At the edges of the plate, the night sky extends up and around a cloud on which the text appears.

component.illusobjdesc: Between three stars, a long-haired, nude female is harnessed to a spherical moon as if to a chariot. The four-stranded harness forks into two parts around her breast and pelvic areas. Holding her arms bent up at the elbows before her, she looks back over her left shoulder toward the sphere as she pulls it to the left across a cloud. She walks left across the surface of the cloud. A band or bracelet may be visible on her left wrist; perhaps her hands are bound.
Pulled left like a chariot by a woman in harness, a large spherical moon with a crescent on its periphery floats in a night sky.

In a dark night sky are three clouds and, at lower left, three prominent stars. The text appears on the topmost cloud, which is set off by a slender border of dark sky on two sides and across the top.

lg.l: Rose up against me thundering from the Brook of Albions River
From Ranelagh & Strumbolo, from Cromwells gardens & Chelsea
The place of wounded Soldiers. but when he saw my Mace
Whirld round from heaven to earth. trembling he sat; his cold
Poisons rose up: & his sweet deceits coverd them all over
With a tender cloud. As thou art now; such was he O Spectre
I know thy deceit & thy revenges, and unless thou desist
I will certainly create an eternal Hell for thee. Listen!
Be attentive! be obedient! Lo the Furnaces are ready to recieve thee.
I will break thee into shivers: & melt thee in the furnaces of death
I will cast thee into forms of abhorrence & torment if thou
Desist not from thine own will, & obey not my stern command:
I am closd up from my children! my Emanation is dividing
And thou my Spectre art divided against me. But mark
I will compell thee to assist me in my terrible labours. To beat
These hypocritic Selfhoods on the Anvils of bitter Death
I am inspired! I act not for myself: for Albions sake
I now am what I am! a horror and an astonishment
Shuddring the heavens to look upon me: Behold what cruelties
Are practised in Babel & Shinar, & have approachd to Zions Hill
While Los spoke, the terrible Spectre fell shuddring before him
Watching his time with glowing eyes to leap upon his prey
Los opend the Furnaces in fear, the Spectre saw to Babel & Shinar
Across all Europe & Asia. he saw the tortures of the Victims.
He saw now from the ouside what he before saw & felt from within"ouside": i.e., "outside".
He saw that Los was the sole, uncontrolld Lord of the Furnaces
Groaning he kneeld before Los's iron-shod feet on London Stone,
Hungring & thirsting for Los's life yet pretending obedience.
While Los pursud his speech in threatnings loud & fierce.
Thou art my Pride & Self-righteousness; I have found thee out:
Thou art reveald before me in all thy magnitude & power
Thy Uncircumcised pretences to Chastity must be cut in sunder!
Thy holy wrath & deep deceit cannot avail against me
Nor shalt thou ever assume the triple-form of Albions Spectre
For I am one of the living: dare not to mock my inspired fury
If thou wast cast forth from my life! if I was dead upon the mountains
Thou mightest be pitied & lovd: but now I am living; unless
Thou abstain ravening I will create an eternal Hell for thee.
Take thou this Hammer & in patience heave the thundering Bellows
Take thou these Tongs: strike thou alternate with me: labour obedient
Hand & Hyle & Koban: Skofeld. Kox & Kotope. labour mightily
In the Wars of Babel & Shinar, all their Emanations were
Condensd. Hand has absorbd all his Brethren in his might
All the infant Loves & Graces were lost. for the mighty Hand

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vignette of wild and pastoral elements, both vegetative and animal, separates lines 12 and 13 of the text, its overall (left to right) displacement of the uncultivated or untamed by the cultivated or tamed perhaps illustrating "the labour of the husbandman" (line 12). At far left, a tiger(?) reposes amidst dense vegetation. Next to it, an ambiguous creature—a feral cat(?)—runs to greet a human figure who kneels and holds an indeterminate object. Between the figure and a flock of grazing sheep at right is a sleeping lion. The thick underbrush near the left margin gives way to a landscape of pasture and mountain peaks. Leaning against a tree at far right, around whose lower trunk a vine grows, is the shepherd-piper of the flock. The vine descends from the tree down the right margin, transforming into a serpent as it veers left, in this way linking the top and middle designs of the plate.

component.illusobjdesc: At far left of the vignette separating lines 12-13 of the text, a tiger(?) (its back appears to be striped) reposes with head resting on paws amidst dense vegetation.

Right of the tiger at rest near the left edge of the vignette separating lines 12-13 of the text, an ambiguous creature—a feral cat(?)—runs toward a kneeling human figure at right. The cat's tail is notably serpentine.

Between lines 12-13 of the text, a figure kneels, facing left, and holds an indeterminate object: perhaps a bowl of victuals for the wild cat(?) headed in its general direction, the domesticating gesture illustrating the "labour of the husbandman" (line 12).
A lion sleeps between a kneeling figure (at left) and a flock of sheep (at right) in the vignette below line 12 of the text.

Right of the wild beasts in the vignette between lines 12 and 13 is a pastoral scene: a flock of sheep grazes in a pasture, which is bordered by mountains whose peaks are visible in the background. At right, the shepherd-piper of the flock leans against a tree. Below the penultimate word ("the") in line 12 is a ram; to its left, a ewe apparently suckles her lamb.

At far right, the shepherd of the flock leans against a tree playing his pipe, his left foot crossed over his right. There is an unidentifiable object held in the crook of his left arm. He wears a plumed cap.

Near the top right corner of the plate, the shepherd- piper watching over his sheep leans against a tree whose branches arch overhead. Beside it is the outline of a second tree—or possibly a thick root. A vine grows round the lower trunk of the first tree and descends the margin, bifurcating near line 17: one tendril splits prominently again, each of its offshoots terminating in loops; the other continues down, loops, and then veers left between lines 23 and 24, transforming into the serpent of the second vignette. A detached serpentine motif appears right of "arrow:" in line 6.

The vegetation of the vignette separating lines 12 and 13 of the text is constituted of both wild and pastoral elements: at far left, a tiger(?) reposes amidst dense leaves and/or unruly tufts of grass; the thick underbrush gives way at right to grassy pastureland on which a flock of sheep grazes. Mountain peaks are visible in the distance.

illustration.illusobjdesc: At far left, midway down the plate (between lines 23 and 24), a hunched-over male(?) figure sits with arms and legs extended and head bowed. To the right, a long-haired, gowned female kneels beside a serpent (the transformed vine of the upper vignette), whose head she touches or pets; from it she accepts an indeterminate oval-shaped object, the apparent transaction between the two suggesting a possible identification of the woman with Eve (and, by extension, the man with Adam?). Landscape details are discernible only near the margins of the design: the serpent slithers over a plot of grass at far right; at left, some indeterminate vegetation frames the sleeping(?) male.

component.illusobjdesc: At far left, midway down the plate (between lines 23 and 24), a hunched-over male(?) sits or sleeps with arms and legs extended and head bowed. Given his proximity to the female fraternizing with a serpent, he may be an Adam figure.

Beside the hunched-over male in the vignette between lines 23 and 24 (midway down the plate), a long-haired, gowned female kneels beside a serpent (the transformed vine of the upper vignette). The folds of her garment cascade behind her. Stroking(?) or touching the serpent with her left hand, she retrieves from beneath its head an indeterminate oval-shaped object with her right, the apparent transaction between the two suggesting a possible identification of the woman with Eve. These associations are tentative: one might interpret her gesture as an act of giving rather than receiving, for instance. In this vein, it is possible that the woman is giving the indeterminate oval-shaped object to the serpent; she may be feeding him, in a parallel to the above vignette which may be illustrating "the labour of the husbandman" (line 12). She seems to glance behind her, or else in the direction of the viewer.

In the vignette between lines 23 and 24 (midway down the plate), a female kneels beside a serpent (the transformed vine of the upper design). Its mouth is open and its tongue just visible. Stroking the serpent with her left hand just below the prominent crest on its head, the woman retrieves from beneath its head an indeterminate oval-shaped object with her right, the apparent transaction between the two suggesting a possible identification of the woman with Eve and, by extension, the serpent with Satan(?). These associations are tentative: the serpent, for instance, may have an amiable rather than sinister aspect. In this vein, it is possible that the woman is giving the indeterminate oval-shaped object to the serpent; she may be feeding him, in a parallel to the above vignette which may be illustrating "the labour of the husbandman" (line 12). Its undulations terminate in a coil at far right, where the creature merges with the vine descending from the tree above.

Landscape details in the vignette between lines 23 and 24 (about midway down the plate) are discernible only near the margins of the design: the serpent slithers over a grassy plot of earth at far right; at left, some indeterminate vegetation consisting of leaves, shrubs, and/or tufts of grass frames the sleeping(?) male.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Across the bottom third of the plate are five gowned mourners, all apparently female (though the gender of the one at far right is ambiguous), lamenting over the nude body of the sleeping Albion. He lies supine on a flat, grassy surface with arms raised horizontally, eyes closed, and head—in the foreground—tilted back so that his lifeless expression is clearly visible to the viewer. The mourner to Albion's left kneels prostrate beside him, her prominent right hand near his face. The mourner at right buries her(?) head between her knees; her left foot is visible from beneath the folds of her garment. Three more females grieve at far left: two stand weeping in identical postures, their hands covering their faces. Interposed between them and the prostrate woman, another female, the only mourner whose countenance is visible, tears her hair in vexation, her eyes raised upward. Dark clouds and a sky rent by lightning appear in the background. Two conspicuous stars, their disproportionally large size suggesting, perhaps, that they are falling to the earth, flank Albion's (also conspicuous) feet.

component.illusobjdesc: At the bottom of the plate, a dead, injured, or sleeping nude male lies supine on a flat grassy surface with arms outstretched along the ground in cruciform position, eyes closed, and head—in the foreground—tilted back so that his lifeless expression is clearly visible to the viewer. He most likely represents the disease-ridden ("I saw disease forming a Body of Death" [line 10] ), sleeping Albion, over whom weep, in Plate 4, "nurses," "mothers," "sisters," and "daughters" (line 16). The figure's long hair spreads out, neatly parted, on either side of his head. His prominent feet form part of the skyline, flanked by two conspicuously large stars.

At far left of the design at the bottom of the plate, two gowned, long-haired females, their postures identical, lament over the nude, supine Albion. Their grief is evidenced by their gestures: each stands facing right, with head bowed and shoulders hunched, and covers her face with her hands. The two mourners, who appear more youthful(?) than the hair-tearing figure right and front of them, may be the "sisters," "daughters," or "nurses" who weep over Albion in Plate 4 (line 16).

Kneeling between the two females covering their faces with their hands (at left) and the prostrate woman (at right) is a fourth female, gowned like the others, and, also like them, distraught over the outstretched, nude body of Albion. Her gestures and general demeanor signify her grief: the only mourner whose countenance is visible, she casts her eyes upward and tears her hair in vexation. She may be one of the "nurses," "mothers," or "daughters" who lament over Albion in Plate 4 (line 16).

In the design at the bottom of the plate, a gowned, presumably female mourner kneels prostrate beside the outstretched, nude Albion at right. Though the palm of her prominent right hand rests on the ground near the body, her fingers are raised as though she were about to touch Albion's face. Her hair, difficult to distinguish from his, nevertheless appears long. She may be one of the "nurses," "mothers," or "daughters who lament over Albion in Plate 4 (line 16).

In the design at the bottom of the plate, near the right margin, a gowned, long-haired female(?) (the figure's gender is ambiguous, but the attire and long hair are consistent with the uniform appearance of the other mourners, all female) sits in a contracted position—with shoulders hunched and legs drawn up—and buries her head between her knees. From beneath the folds of her garment emerges her left foot, positioned, like the prostrate mourner's hand at left, near the sleeping Albion's head. She may be one of the "nurses," "mothers," or "daughters" of Plate 4 who lament over Albion (line 16).

At bottom, a flat, grassy surface extends the width of the plate. In the foreground at far right, directly in front of the hunched-over mourner's left foot, is a single, detached leaf. Behind the two weeping females in the left margin are shrubs or leafy treetops.

Dark clouds and (paradoxically) a well-lit sky (perhaps rent by lightning) appear in the background of the major design at the bottom of the plate. Two conspicuous stars, their disproportionally large size suggesting, perhaps, that they are falling to the earth, flank Albion's (also conspicuous) feet.
In the right margin following lines 30-35, the ambiguous shape ensconced in the hollow beneath the vegetative surface of the plate's middle vignette may be a winged figure(?).

l.note: Blake may have etched numbers, top right, on all the plates, but only a small percentage of them printed in Copy E. Here, a "9" in black line is partially visible just below the pen-and-ink numeral "9" of line 1.

lg.l: Condens'd his Emanations into hard opake substances;
And his infant thoughts & desires. into cold. dark. cliffs of death.
His hammer of gold he siez'd; and his anvil of adamant.
He siez'd the bars of condens'd thoughts, to forge them:
Into the sword of war! into the bow and arrow:
Into the thundering cannon and into the murdering gun
I saw the limbs form'd for exercise, contemn'd: & the beauty of
Eternity, look'd upon as deformity & loveliness as a dry tree:
I saw disease forming a Body of Death around the Lamb
Of God, to destroy Jerusalem. & to devour the body of Albion
By war and stratagem to win the labour of the husbandman:
Awkwardness arm'd in steel: folly in a helmet of gold:
Weakness with horns & talons: ignorance with a rav'ning beak!
Every Emanative joy forbidden as a Crime:
And the Emanations buried alive in the earth with pomp of religion:
Inspiration deny'd; Genius forbidden by laws of punishment:
I saw terrified; I took the sighs & tears. & bitter groans:
I lifted them into my Furnaces; to form the spiritual sword.
That lays open the hidden heart: I drew forth the pang
Of sorrow red hot: I workd it on my resolute anvil:
I heated it in the flames of Hand, & Hyle, & Coban
Nine times; Gwendolen & Cambel & Gwineverra
Are melted into the gold, the silver, the liquid ruby,
The crysolite, the topaz. the jacinth. & every precious stone.
Loud roar my Furnaces and loud my hammer is heard:
I labour day and night, I behold the soft affections
Condense beneath my hammer into forms of cruelty
But still I labour in hope, tho' still my tears flow down.
That he who will not defend Truth, may be compelld to defend
A Lie: that he may be snared and caught and snared and taken
That Enthusiasm and Life may not cease: arise Spectre arise!
Thus they contended among the Furnaces with groans & tears;
Groaning the Spectre heavd the bellows. obeying Los's frowns;
Till the Spaces of Erin were perfected in the furnaces
Of affliction, and Los drew them forth. compelling the harsh. Spectre.

lg.l: Into the Furnaces & into the valleys of the Anvils of Death
And into the mountains of the Anvils & of the heavy Hammers
Till he should bring the Sons & Daughters of Jerusalem to be
The Sons & Daughters of Los that he might protect them from
Albions dread Spectres: storming, loud, thunderous & mighty
The Bellows & the Hammers move compell'd by Los's hand.
And this is the manner of the Sons of Albion in their strength
They take the Two Contraries which are calld Qualities, with which
Every Substance is clothed, they name them Good & Evil
From them they make an Abstract. which is a Negation
Not only of the Substance from which it is derived
A murderer of its own Body: but also a murderer
Of every Divine Member: it is the Reasoning Power
An Abstract objecting power, that Negatives every thing
This is the Spectre of Man; the Holy Reasoning Power
And in its Holiness is closed the Abomination of Desolation
Therefore Los stands in London building Golgonooza
Compelling his Spectre to labours mighty; trembling in fear
The Spectre weeps. but Los unmovd by tears or threats remains
I must Create a System. or be enslav'd by another Mans
I will not Reason & Compare: my business is to Create
So Los, in fury & strength: in indignation & burning wrath
Shuddring the Spectre howls. his howlings terrify the night
He stamps around the Anvil, beating blows of stern despair
He curses Heaven & Earth. Day & Night & Sun & Moon
He curses Forest Spring & River, Desart & sandy Waste
Cities & Nations, Families & Peoples, Tongues & Laws
Driven to desperation by Loss terrors & threatning fears"Loss": i.e., "Los's".
Los cries, Obey my voice & never deviate from my will
And I will be merciful to thee: be thou invisible to all
To whom I make thee invisible, but chief to my own Children
O Spectre of Urthona: Reason not against their dear approach
Nor them obstruct with thy temptations of doubt & despair
O Shame O strong & mighty Shame I break thy brazen fetters
If thou refuse, thy present torments will seem southern breezes
To what thou shalt endure if thou obey not my great will.
The Spectre answer'd. Art thou not ashamd of those thy Sins
That thou callest thy Children? lo the Law of God commands
That they be offered upon his Altar; O cruelty & torment
For thine are also mine! I have kept silent hitherto.
Concerning my chief delight: but thou hast broken silence
Now I will speak my mind! Where is my lovely Enitharmon
O thou my enemy, where is my Great Sin? She is also thine
I said: now is my grief at worst: incapable of being
Surpassed: but every moment it accumulates more & more
It continues accumulating to eternity; the joys of God advance
For he is Righteous: he is not a Being of Pity & Compassion
He cannot feel Distress: he feeds on Sacrifice & Offering:
Delighting in cries & tears & clothed in holiness & solitude
But my griefs advance also, for ever & ever without end
O that I could cease to be! Despair! I am Despair
Created to be the great example of horror & agony! also my
Prayer is vain I called for compassion: compassion mockd
Mercy & pity threw the grave stone over me & with lead
And iron, bound it over me for ever: Life lives on my
Consuming: & the Almighty hath made me his Contrary
To be all evil. all reversed & for ever dead: knowing
And seeing life. yet living not; how can I then behold
And not tremble; how can I be beheld & not abhorrd
So spoke the Spectre shuddring, & dark tears ran down his shadowy faceAfter the initial letters "sh", the phrase "shadowy face" is inscribed vertically in the right margin.
Which Los wiped off, but comfort none could give! or beam of hope
Yet ceasd he not from labouring at the roarings of his Forge
With iron & brass Building Golgonooza in great contendings
Till his Sons & Daughters came forth from the Furnaces
At the sublime Labours for Los. compelld the invisible Spectre

illustration.illusobjdesc: A hybrid woman/swan dominates the major design at the top of the plate: the legs, waist, and breasts are those of a woman; but the wings, neck and head are decidedly swan-like. She kneels facing right in a lake or river, the trees and grassy banks of the shoreline visible behind her. A small fish swims to her left. The swan-woman arches her long neck down to the water, perhaps to eat. In the background the rosy palette of the sky suggests the time is sunrise or sunset.

component.illusobjdesc: A hybrid creature—part woman, part swan—dominates the design at the top of the plate: the legs, waist, and breasts are those of a woman; but the wings, neck and head are decidedly swan-like. Facing right, she kneels in or floats on a lake or river, arching her long neck down to the water so that her bill and throat rest on its surface; the bubbles that disturb the eddies and currents at right indicate she may be feeding. There is a band beneath her breasts suggesting that at least her lower half may be covered by one of Blake's transparent gowns (or in this case a skirt).
Left of the swan-woman at the top of the plate, a fish swims with mouth open (as do the interlinear aquatic creatures in the right margin of the middle text panel).

The swan-woman at the top of the plate kneels in a lake or river, the trees and grassy banks of the shoreline visible behind her. Long, slender branches—willow-like, though partially obscured by added leafage in the present copy—arch down to the water from the tree at right.
The rosy palette of a sky streaked with clouds in the plate's topmost design suggests the time is sunrise or sunset.
