lg.l: I have heard Jerusalems groans; from Vala's cries & lamentations
I gather our eternal fate: Outcasts from life and love:
Unless we find a way to bind these awful Forms to our
Embrace we shall perish annihilate, discoverd our Delusions.
Look I have wrought without delusion: Look! I have wept!
And given soft milk mingled together with the spirits of flocks
Of lambs and doves, mingled together in cups and dishes
Of painted clay; the mighty Hyle is become a weeping infant;
Soon shall the Spectres of the Dead follow my weaving threads.
The Twelve Daughters of Albion attentive listen in secret shades
On Cambridge and Oxford beaming soft uniting with Rahabs cloud
While Gwendolen spoke to Cambel turning soft the spinning reel:
Or throwing the wingd shuttle; or drawing the cords with softest songs
The golden cords of the Looms animate beneath their touches soft,
Along the Island white. among the Druid Temples, while Gwendolen
Spoke to the Daughters of Albion standing on Skiddaws top.
So saying she took a Falshood & hid it in her left hand:
To entice her Sisters away to Babylon on Euphrates.
And thus she closed her left hand and utterd her Falshood:
Forgetting that Falshood is prophetic, she hid her hand behind her,
Upon her back behind her loins & thus utterd her Deceit.
I heard Enitharmon say to Los! Let the Daughters of Albion
Be scatterd abroad and let the name of Albion be forgotten:
Divide them into three; name them Amalek Canaan & Moab.
Let Albion remain a desolation without an inhabitant:
And let the Looms of Enitharmon & the Furnaces of Los
Create Jerusalem. & Babylon & Egypt & Moab & Amalek.
And Helle & Hesperia & Hindostan & China & Japan.
But hide America, for a Curse an Altar of Victims & a Holy Place.
See Sisters Canaan is pleasant, Egypt is as the Garden of Eden:
Babylon is our chief desire. Moab our bath in summer:
Let us lead the stems of this Tree let us plant it before Jerusalem
To judge the Friend of Sinners to death without the Veil:
To cut her off from America. to close up her secret Ark!
And the fury of Man exhaust in War, Woman permanent remain
See how the fires of our loins point eastward to Babylon
Look. Hyle is become an infant Love; look: behold! see him lie!
Upon my bosom. look! here is the lovely wayward form
That gave me sweet delight by his torments beneath my Veil;
By the fruit of Albions Tree I have fed him with sweet milk
By contentions of the mighty for Sacrifice of Captives:
Humanity the Great Delusion: is changd to War & Sacrifice;

I have naild his hands on Beth Rabbim & his hands on Heshbons Wall;Erdman replaces the second "hands" with "feet" (Erdman pages 240, 812n). Bentley acknowledges the possibility of error but does not emend (Bentley page 600n).
O that I could live in his sight; O that I could bind him to my arm.
So saying: She drew aside her Veil from Mam-Tor to Dovedale
Discovering her own perfect beauty to the Daughters of Albion

And Hyle a winding Worm beneathBlake deleted the last half of line 48 and the first half of the following line from the copperplate. Erdman recovers the deleted material (in square brackets) as follows (Erdman page 812n): "And Hyle a winding worm beneath [her Loom upon the scales. Hyle was become a winding Worm:] & not a weeping Infant".
& not a weeping Infant.
Trembling & pitying she screamd & fled upon the wind:
Hyle was a winding Worm and herself perfect in beauty;
The desarts tremble at his wrath; they shrink themselves in fear.
Cambel trembled with jealousy: she trembled! she envied!
The envy ran thro Cathedrons Looms into the Heart
Of mild Jerusalem. to destroy the Lamb of God. Jerusalem
Languishd upon Mount Olivet. East of mild Zions Hill.
Los saw the envious blight above his Seventh Furnace
On Londons Tower on the Thames: he drew Cambel in wrath.
Into his thundering Bellows, heaving it for a loud blast!
And with the blast of his Furnace upon fishy Billingsgate.
Beneath Albions fatal Tree. before the Gate of Los;
Shewd her the fibres of her beloved to ameliorate
The envy; loud she labourd in the Furnace of fire,
To form the mighty form of Hand according to her will.
In. the Furnaces of Los & in the Wine-press treading day & night
Naked among the human clusters: bringing wine of anguish
To feed the afflicted in the Furnaces; she minded not

The raging flames, tho she returndBlake deleted the last half of line 68 and the first half of the following line from the copperplate. Erdman recovers the deleted material (in square brackets) as follows (Erdman page 812n): "The raging flames, tho she returnd [consumd day after day A redning skeleton in howling woe] instead of beauty".
:instead of beauty
Defomity: she gave her beauty to another: bearing abroad"Defomity": i.e., "Deformity".
Her struggling torment in her iron arms: and like a chain.
Binding his wrists & ankles with the iron arms of love,
Gwendolen saw the Infant in her sistes arms: she howld"sistes": i.e., "sisters".
Over the forests with bitter tears, and over the winding Worm
Repentant: and she also in the eddying wind of Los's Bellows
Began her dolorous task of love in the Wine-press of Luvah
To form the Worm into a form of love by tears & pain.
The Sisters saw! trembling ran thro their Looms! softeng mild"softeng": i.e., "softening".
Towards London: then they saw the Furnaes opend, & in tears"Furnaes": i.e., "Furnaces".
Began to give their souls away in the Furnaes of affliction."Furnaes": i.e., "Furnaces".
Los saw & was comforted at his Furnaces uttering thus his voice.
I know I am Urthona keeper of the Gates of Heaven.
And that I can at will expatiate in the Gardens of bliss;
But pangs of love draw me down to my loins which are
Become a fountain of veiny pipes: O Albion! my brother!

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text of the plate is written on a voluminous cloud, whose vermicular seam in the right margin gives way to a patch of dark sky that extends from about a third of the way down the plate to the top right corner. The outlines of background clouds are also discernible in the lower right margin. At the point where the cloud's larger, upper undulations start to become tighter and more convoluted, a nude figure, seen from behind, lunges headfirst into the billowing mass, left arm extended. Further down, a second figure, this one clothed, sits facing left atop one of the convolutions, right of "Thames" in line 51. The figure's left arm is on its lap, and it may be wearing a cap.

component.illusobjdesc: The text of the plate is written on a voluminous cloud, whose vermicular seam in the middle of the right margin gives way to larger, upper undulations about three quarters of the way up from the bottom of the plate. The outlines of background clouds are discernible in the lower right margin, and blue sky peeks from behind the cloud in the upper margin (with a smaller patch of blue visible just above the bottom right corner).

At the point where the cloud's larger, upper undulations start to become tighter and more convoluted, a nude, male(?) figure, seen from behind, lunges headfirst into the billowing mass, left arm extended, palm out. Only the toes of the figure's right foot make contact with the cloud. A thin line discernible beneath the figure's arm may be a strand of hair.

A sketchy gowned figure sits facing left, head bowed, on top of a cloud right of "Thames" in line 51. Its left arm rests on its lap, and its legs are extended. The figure may be wearing a cap or headgear of some sort.

lg.l: Corrupability appears upon thy limbs. and never more"corrupability": i.e., corruptibility". In Copy E Blake seems to have attempted, unsuccessfully, to mend the word as etched, "Corrupability", in pen (?) (but cf. Erdman page 812n, Bentley pages 802-03n).
Can I arise and leave thy side, but labour here incessant
Till thy awaking! yet alas I shall forget Eternity!
Against the Patriarchal pomp and cruelty. labouring incessant
I shall become an Infant horror. Enion! Tharmas! friends
Absorb me not in such dire grief: O Albion. my brother!
Jerusalem hungers in the desart; affection to her children!
The scorn'd and contemnd youthful girl, where shall she fly?
Sussex shuts up her Villages. Hants, Devon & Wilts
Surrounded with masses of stone in orderd forms. determine then
A form for Vala and a form for Luvah. here on the Thames
Where the Victim nightly howls beneath the Druids knife;
A Form of Vegetation, nail them down on the stems of Mystery;
O when shall the Saxon return with the English his redeemed brother!
O when shall the Lamb of God descend among the Reprobate!
I woo to Amalek to protect my fugitives Amalek trembles:
I call to Canaan & Moab in my night watches, they mourn:
They listen not to my cry, they rejoce among their warriors"rejoce": i.e., "rejoice".
Woden and Thor and Friga wholly consume my Saxons:
On their enormous Altars built in the terrible north:
From Irelands rocks to Scandinavia Persia and Tartary:
From the Atlantic Sea to the universal Erythrean.
Found ye London! enormous City! weeps thy River?
Upon his parent bosom lay thy little ones O Land
Forsaken. Surrey and Sussex are Enitharmons Chamber.
Where I will build her a Couch of repose & my pillars
Shall surround her in beautiful labyrinths: Oothoon?
Where hides my child? in Oxford hidest thou with Antamon?
In graceful hidings of error: in merciful deceit
Lest Hand the terrible destroy his Affection, thou hidest her:Blake mended "affection" to "Affection" on the copperplate.
In chaste appearances for sweet deceits of love & modesty
Immingled, interwoven, glistening to the sickening sight.
Let Cambel and her Sisters sit within the Mundane Shell:
Forming the fluctuating Globe according to their will.
According as they weave the little embryon nerves & veins
The Eye. the little Nostrils. & the delicate Tongue & Ears
Of labyrinthine intricacy: so shall they fold the World
That whatever is seen upon the Mundane Shell, the same
Be seen upon the Fluctuating Earth woven by the Sisters.
And sometimes the Earth shall roll in the Abyss & sometimes
Stand in the Center & sometimes stretch flat in the Expanse.
According to the will of the lovely Daughters of Albion.
Sometimes it shall assimilate with mighty Golgonooza:
Touching its summits: & sometimes divided roll apart.
As a beautiful Veil so these Females shall fold & unfold
According to their will the outside surface of the Earth

An outside shadowy Surface superadded to the real Surface;The first letter of "Surface" was written in acid-resist as both a lower-case "s" and an upper-case "S". Both letters were etched, and both print in Copy E.
Which is unchangeable for ever & ever Amen: so be it!
Separate Albions Sons gently from their Emanations
Weaving bowers of delight on the current of infant Thames
Where the old Parent still retains his youth as I alas!
Retain my youth eight thousand and five hundred years.
The labourer of ages in the Valleys of Despair;
The land is markd for desolation & unless we plant
The seeds of Cities & of Villages in the Human bosom
Albion must be a rock of blood: mark ye the points
Where Cities shall remain & where Villages for the rest:
It must lie in confusion till Albions time of awaking.
Place the Tribes of Llewellyn in America for a hiding place!
Till sweet Jerusalem emanates again into Eternity
The night falls thick: I go upon my watch: be attentive:
The Sons of Albion go forth; I follow from my Furnaces:
That they return no more: that a place be prepard on Euphrates
Listen to your Watchmans voice: sleep not before the Furnaces
Eternal Death stands at the door, O God pity our labours.
So Los spoke. to the Daughters of Beulah while his Emanation
Like a faint rainbow waved before him in the awful gloom
Of London City on the Thames from Surrey Hills to Highgate:
Swift turn the silver spindles, & the golden weights play soft
And lulling harmonies beneath the Looms, from Caithness in the north
To Lizard-point & Dover in the south: his Emanation
Joy'd in the many weaving threads in bright Cathedrons Dome
Weaving the Web of life for Jerusalem. the Web of life
Down flowing into Entuthons Vales glistens with soft affections.
While Los arose upon his Watch. and down from Golgonooza
Putting on his golden sandals to walk from mountain to mountain
He takes his way, girding himself with gold & in his hand
Holding his iron mace: The Spectre remains attentive
Alternate they watch on night; alternate labour in day
Before the Furnaces labouring. while Los all night watches
The stars rising & setting, & the meteors & terrors of night.
With him went down the Dogs of Leutha at his feet
They lap the water of the trembling Thames then follow swift
And thus he heard the voice of Albions daughters on Euphrates,(-lah
Our Father Albions land: O it was a lovely land! & the Daughters of Beu-
Walked up and down in its green mountains: but Hand is fled

textfoot.l: Away: & mighty Hyle; & after them Jerusalem is gone,AwakeErdman comments on "Awake", the final word on the plate: "Whether given an exclamation point or not, this word seems to hang in mid-air"—and goes on to note the differences in "lettering, technique, content" that separate this plate from its successor (Erdman page 812n). He supposes that Plate 84 "obviously did not originally follow" Plate 83. Paley adds: "Although the lamentation of the Daughters continues from the end of 83, the last line of the latter does not lead into 84: 1" (Paley page 273n). A more satisfactory hypothesis is that "Awake" is a catchword, as its placement suggests, and that Plate 83 was originally designed to precede what is now Plate 97. In that arrangement, Jerusalem's decline at the end of Plate 83 is immediately followed by a call for her to awake at the top of Plate 97.

objnote.p: See the note on line 89 of Object 83 for comment on the continuity of Objects 83-84.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the foreground, a gowned, curly-haired child leads a fully gowned old man with long beard and hair along a paved street (compare the similar design, reversed, for "London" in Songs of Experience). These basic elements correspond generally with the description in lines 12-13 of "London blind & age-bent begging thro the Streets / Of Babylon, led by a child. his tears run down his beard." Though there are no discernible tears, the old man's eyes are closed or vacant. He walks in a hunched position with crutches. Apparently in mid-stride, the child seems to turn and reach back with his left arm; his right arm is extended forward and down. The old man's back is profiled against a stone wall. The wall and street are cut by strong shadows from the right. Left of the wall, in the background, are icons of Westminster Abbey and St. Paul's Cathedral: a Gothic church with spires and an arched doorway; behind it to the right, a cross-topped turret and dome. Behind them the sun rises or sets above a hill.

At top left, above a high horizon that appears to be the top of a hill, a dark sky is lit by the beams of light from a rising or setting sun.

lg.l: Highgates heights & Hampsteads, to Poplar Hackney & Bow:
To Islington & Paddington & the Brook of Albions River
We builded Jerusalem as a City & a Temple: from Lambeth
We began our Foundations; lovely Lambeth! O lovely Hills
Of Camberwell, we shall behold you no more in glory & pride
For Jerusalem lies in ruins & the Furnaces of Los are builded there
You are now shrunk up to a narrow Rock in the midst of the Sea
But here we build Babylon on Euphrates. compelld to build
And to inhabit. our Little-ones to clothe in armour of the gold
Of Jerusalems Cherubims & to forge them swords of her Altars
I see London blind & age-bent begging thro the Streets
Of Babylon, led by a child. his tears run down his beard
The voice of Wandering Reuben ecchoes from street to street
In all the Cities of the Nations Paris Madrid Amsterdam
The Corner of Broad Street weeps; Poland Street languishes
To Great Queen Street & Lincolns Inn all is distress & woe.

l.note: The remaining letter fragments indicate that Blake deleted three lines from the copper after line 17.

lg.l: The night falls thick Hand comes from Albion in his strength
He combines into a Mighty-one the Double Molech & Chemosh
Marching thro Egypt in his fury the East is pale at his course
The Nations of India, the Wild Tartar that never knew Man
Starts from his lofty places & casts down his tents & flees away
But we woo him all the night in songs, O Los come forth O Los
Divide us from these terrors & give us power them to subdue
Arise upon thy Watches let us see thy Globe of fire
On Albions Rocks & let thy voice be heard upon Euphrates.
Thus sang the Daughters in lamentation, uniting into One
With Rahab as she turnd the iron Spindle of destruction.
Terrified at the Sons of Albion they took the Falshood which
Gwendolen hid in her left hand. it grew &, grew till it

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design at the bottom of the plate shows Enitharmon drawing out Los's fibres: "I will sieze thy Fibres & weave / Them" (Plate 87, lines 13-14; see, in general, Plate 87, lines 4-24 and plate 88, lines 23-34). Los is seated at left with his left leg drawn back under his thigh, buttock resting on his left foot. His right leg is bent at the knee with right foot planted squarely on the ground. His upper body is twisted clockwise to face left, and his left arm is bent upward in a defensive gesture. Three long, vine-like strands, which send forth leaves and bunches of grapes, are being pulled from his body, one each from the areas of his left underarm, his lower abdomen, and his groin. These three strands are held aloft together in Enitharmon's left hand. She kneels with both knees facing left, but she is twisted at the waist presenting her full back and is seen in right profile. Her long, serpentine lock of hair streams to the left. Both figures are nude. Enitharmon plies the three sections of entrails, which morph into well-leafed vines of another variety in her right hand (though the two sections are not continuous) after passing under two ambiguous objects (stones? fruit? stones or fruit doubling as testicles?) that she holds in her open right palm. Two more vines similar in kind extend from her waist area. Despite their close physical proximity to each other (their knees touch), the figures appear temporally distanced: the sky behind Los is hung with nighttime celestial motifs (crescent moon, comet, star, plus a vermicular cloud at far left), while that behind Enitharmon is colored in a rosy palette with blazing sun in the upper corner, suggesting the time is sunrise, or an odd fusion of sunrise and full daylight. The grassy turf on which the figures kneel is seemingly edged with moss and lichens or other vegetation that extends up the left edge of the design.

component.illusobjdesc: The design at the bottom of the plate shows Enitharmon drawing out Los's fibres: "I will sieze thy Fibres & weave / Them" (Plate 87, lines 13-14; see, in general, Plate 87, lines 4-24 and plate 88, lines 23-34). Los is nude and has short, curly hair. He is seated at left with his left leg drawn back under his thigh, buttock resting on his left foot, and knee touching Enitharmon's. His right leg is bent at the knee with right foot planted squarely on the ground. His upper body is twisted to the left, head bowed, as opposed to his knees which face right, and his left arm is bent upward in a defensive gesture (which also suggests pain), palm facing down and slightly out. His right hand is flat on the ground with the index finger long and (perhaps) root-like. Three long, vine-like strands, which send forth leaves and bunches of grapes, are being pulled from his body, one each from the areas of his left underarm, his lower abdomen, and his groin. His mouth is slightly open.

The design at the bottom of the plate shows a nude Enitharmon drawing out Los's fibres (cf. Plate 87, lines 4-24 and plate 88, lines 23-34), which are held aloft together in her left hand. She kneels with both knees facing left (her right knee touches Albion's left), but she is twisted at the waist presenting her full back and is seen in right profile. Her long, serpentine lock of hair streams to the left. Enitharmon plies the three sections of entrails, which morph into well-leafed vines of another variety in her right hand (though the two sections are not continuous) after passing under two ambiguous objects (stones? fruit? stones or fruit doubling as testicles?) that she holds in her open right palm. Two more vines similar in kind extend from her waist area.

Though in close physical proximity to each other (their knees touch), the figures in the design at the bottom of the plate appear temporally distanced: the sky behind Los is hung with nighttime celestial motifs: a waning crescent moon lower left above the horizon; a star nestled in the lower curve of a vermicular cloud; and a blazing pinwheel comet racing toward the dawn (or combination dawn/daytime) sky backing Enitharmon at right, whose sun, drawn with concentric rings, rises in the upper right corner.

In the main design at the bottom of the plate, three long, vine-like strands are being pulled from Los's body, one each from the areas of his left underarm, his lower abdomen, and his groin. Three leaves that appear to be transforming into stars grow from the upper vines, and a ripe bunch of grapes hangs from the juncture where two strands merge. The groin structure has a grape leaf, a bunch of grapes, and a loopy tendril. Enitharmon plies the three sections of fibres, which morph into well-leafed vines of another variety in her right hand (though the two sections at right and left are not continuous) after passing under two ambiguous objects (stones? fruit? stones or fruit doubling as testicles?) that she holds in her open right palm; the middle vine terminates in a flower, the upper in frayed fibres with clumps of earth suggesting roots. Two more vines similar in kind extend from her waist area. The grassy turf on which the figures kneel is seemingly edged with moss and lichens, a vegetative mix which continues up the left margin.

lg.l: Became a Space & an Allegory around the Winding Worm
They namd it Canaan & built for it a tender Moon
Los smild with joy thinking on Enitharmon & he brought
Reuben from his twelvefold wandrings & led him into it
Planting the Seeds of the Twelwe Tribes & Moses & David"Twelwe": i.e., "Twelve". In Copy E, there is an extra stroke in the "v", making it appear to be a "w".
And gave a Time & Revolution to the Space Six Thousand Years
He calld it Divine Analogy, for in Beulah the Feminine
Emanations Create Space, the Masculine Create Time. & plant
The Seeds of beauty in the Space: listning to their lamentation
Los walks upon his ancient Mountains in the deadly darkness
Among his Furnaces directing his laborious Myriads watchful"myriads" was revised on the copperplate to "Myriads".
Looking to the East: & his voice is heard over the whole Earth
As he watches the Furnaces by night, & directs the labourers
And thus Los replies upon his Watch: the Valleys listen silent:
The Stars stand still to hear: Jerusalem & Vala cease to mourn!
His voice is heard from Albion: the Alps & Appenines
Listen: Hermon & Lebanon bow their crowned heads
Babel & Shinar look toward the Western Gate, they sit down
Silent at his voice: they view the red Globe of fire in Los's hand
As he walks from Furnace to Furnace directing the Labourers
And this is the Song of Los. the Song that he sings on his
Watch
O lovely mild Jerusalem! O Shiloh of Mount Ephraim!
I see thy Gates of precious stones! thy Walls of gold & silver
Thou art the soft reflected Image of the Sleeping Man
Who stretchd on Albions rocks reposes amidst his Twenty-eight
Cities: where Beulah lovely terminates, in the hills & valleys of Albion
Cities not yet embodied in Time and Space: plant ye
The Seeds O Sisters in the bosom of Time & Spaces womb
To spring up for Jerusalem: lovely Shadow of Sleeping Albion
Why wilt thou rend thyself apart & build an Earthly Kingdom
To reign in pride & to opress & to mix the Cup of Delusion
O thou that dwellest with Babylon! Come forth O lovely-one

lg.l: I see thy Form O lovely mild Jerusalem. Wingd with Six Wings
In the opacous Bosom of the Sleeper. lovely Three-fold
In Head & Heart & Reins three Universes of love & beauty
Thy forehead bright: Holiness to the Lord with Gates of pearl
Reflects Eternity beneath thy azure wings of feathery down
Ribbd delicate & clothd with featherd gold & azure & purple
From thy white shoulders shadowing, purity in holiness!
Thence featherd with soft crimson of the ruby bright as fire
Spreading into the azure Wings which like a canopy
Bends over thy immortal Head in which Eternity dwells
Albion beloved Land; I see thy mountains & thy hills
And valleys & thy pleasant Cities Holiness to the Lord
I see the Spectres of thy Dead O Emanation of Albion.
Thy Bosom white. translucent coverd with immortal gems
A sublime ornament not obscuring the outlines of beauty
Terrible to behold for thy extreme beauty & perfection
Twelve-fold, here all the Tribes of Israel I behold
Upon the Holy Land: I see the River of Life & Tree of Life
I see the New Jerusalem descending out of Heaven
Between thy Wings of gold & silver featherd immortal
Clear as the rainbow, as the cloud of the Suns tabernacle
Thy Reins coverd with Wings translucent sometimes covering
And sometimes spread abroad reveal the flames of holiness
Which like a robe covers: & like a Veil of Seraphim
In flaming fire unceasing burns from Eternity to Eternity
Twelvefold I there behold Israel in her Tents
A Pillar of a Cloud by day: a Pillar of fire by night
Guides them: there I behold Moab & Ammon & Amalek
There Bells of silver round thy knees living articulate
Comforting sounds of love & harmony & on thy feet
Sandals of gold & pearl, & Egypt & Assyria before me
The Isles of Javan, Philistea. Tyre and Lebanon
Thus Los sings upon his Watch walking from Furnace to Furnace.In Copy E, part of the second "Furnace", beginning with the letter "a", is written vertically up the side of the plate.
He siezes his Hammer every hour, flames surround him as
He beats: seas roll beneath his feet, tempests muster
Aroud his head. the thick hail stones stand ready to obey"Aroud": i.e., "Around".
His voice in the black cloud, his Sons labour in thunders
At his Furnaces; his Daughters at their Looms sing woes
His Emanation separates in milky fibres agonizing
Among the golden Looms of Cathedron sending Fibres of love
From Golgonooza with sweet visions for Jerusalem. wanderer
Nor can any consummate bliss without being Generated
On Earth; of those whose Emanations weave the loves
Of Beulah for Jerusalem & Shiloh. in immortal Golgonooza
Concentering in the majestic form of Erin in eternal tears
Viewing the Winding Worm on the Desarts of Great Tartary
Viewing Los in his shudderings, pouring balm on his sorrows
So dread is Los's fury. that none dare him to approach
Without becoming his Children in the Furnaces of affliction
And Enitharmon like a faint rainbow waved before him
Filling with Fibres from his loins which reddend with desire
Into a Globe of blood beneath his bosom trembling in darkness
Of Albions clouds. he fed it. with his tears & bitter groans
Hiding his Spectre in invisibility from the timorous Shade
Till it became a separated cloud of beauty grace & love
Among the darkness of his Furnaces dividing asunder till
She separated stood before him a lovely Female weeping
Even Enitharmon separated outside, & his Loins closed
And heal'd after the separation: his pains he soon forgot:
Lured by her beauty outside of himself in shadowy grief.
Two Wills they had; Two Intellects: & not as in times of old.
Silent they wanderd hand in hand like two Infants wandring
From Enion in the desarts, terrified at each others beauty
Envying each other yet desiring, in all devouring Love

illustration.illusobjdesc: The half-plate design shows four contiguous circles (two on top, two on bottom) whose smoke-filled and/or cavernous interiors enclose two figures at left; two more figures wander from their circles at right. The fourfold structure (cf. the bottom design in Milton, Bentley Plate 32) and cavernous space of the circles (which are collectively referred to in lines 2-3 as the "fourfold / Desarts") suggest the Mundane Shell or Egg. The figure in the upper left circle is a nude, bearded male who lunges right but seemingly looks left. His arms are raised horizontally as he pushes against the walls of his sphere. In the circle below him are the sketchy outlines of a face and upper body. The nude pair at right are holding hands; the curly-haired upper figure faces toward the viewer, his companion, away. They most likely represent the youthful Los and Enitharmon who "hand in hand like two infants wand[er] / From Enion" (Plate 86, lines 63-64). The gowned Enion—disproportionally large with respect to the other figures—stoops facing right in front of the lower circles, groping blindly (line 2) for Los and Enitharmon with outstretched arms. In the top right circle of the design there may be the suggestion of a sixth figure, sketchy and difficult to discern, whose arms are bent upward, hands clutching head. The diamond-shaped interstice in the middle of the design is filled with flame-like fibres and colored red to suggest fire, and the smaller crevices at left and right and top and bottom are also fiery.

component.illusobjdesc: A nude, long-haired(?), bearded male is enclosed in the upper left circle of the plate's design. He lunges right but seemingly looks left. His arms are raised horizontally as he pushes against the walls of his sphere.

The sketchy contours of a face and upper body are discernible in the bottom left circle of the main design. Details are vague, but the figure may have its arms folded. Its shoulders appear to be oriented to the right, but the figure looks left.

Hovering in contrapposto in front of the top circle at right, a nude, curly-haired, and youthful male figure holds with his left hand the right hand and/or forearm of a second nude figure below him. Both his arms are raised at approximately 45 degrees, and his right palm is facing down but tilted slightly toward the viewer. He faces forward, but looks down and left, as if toward Enion, the central figure. Notwithstanding the apparent age discrepancy between their pictorial and textual depictions, the pair of figures most likely represents the youthful Los and Enitharmon who "hand in hand like two infants wand[er] / From Enion" (Plate 86, lines 63-64). Miscellaneous lines forming part of the circle's interior appear to do double duty as wings attached(?) to Los.

Hovering in front of the lower circle at right, arms raised vertically, a nude female(?) figure wearing her hair short or in a bun grasps with her right hand the left hand of the male above her; her other hand touches his hip. She is slightly twisted counterclockwise, lower body facing right, upper body facing away from the viewer. Notwithstanding the apparent age discrepancy between their pictorial and textual depictions, the youthful pair most likely represents Los and Enitharmon who "hand in hand like two infants wand[er] / From Enion" (Plate 86, lines 63-64).

The long-haired female—disproportionally large with respect to the other figures in the main design—who walks facing right in a hunched-over posture in front of the lower circles is most likely Enion, "blind & age-bent" (line 2), groping for Los and Enitharmon with outstretched arms. Her gown appears to be belted at the waist. Enion's fingers are spread; her left palm is vertical, her right faces down.
In the top right circle of the design there may be the suggestion of a sixth figure, very sketchy and difficult to discern, whose arms are bent upward, hands clutching head.

The half-plate design shows four contiguous circles (two on top, two on bottom) with smoke-filled and/or cavernous interiors. The fourfold structure (cf. the bottom design in Milton, Bentley Plate 32) and cavernous space of the circles (which are collectively referred to in lines 2-3 as the "fourfold / Desarts") suggest the Mundane Shell or Egg. The diamond- shaped interstice (partially obscured by Enion's upper body) in the middle of the design is filled with flames or flame-like fibres and roots, and colored red to suggest fire. The smaller crevices at left and right and top and bottom are also fiery. At bottom, Enion runs across an indeterminate surface, with, perhaps, suggestions of grass and bare earth.

lg.l: Repelling weeping Enion blind & age-bent into the fourfold
Desarts. Los first broke silence & began to utter his love
O lovely Enitharmon: I behold thy graceful forms
Moving beside me till intoxicated with the woven labyrinth
Of beauty & perfection my wild fibres shoot in veins
Of blood thro all my nervous limbs. soon overgrown in roots
I shall be closed from thy sight. sieze therefore in thy hand
The small fibres as they shoot around me draw out in pity
And let them run on the winds of thy bosom: I will fix them
With pulsations. we will divide them into Sons & Daughters
To live in thy Bosoms translucence as in an eternal morning
Enitharmon answerd, No! I will sieze thy Fibres & weave
Them; not as thou wilt but as I will, for I will Create
A round Womb beneath my bosom lest I also be overwoven
With Love; be thou assured I never will be thy slave
Let Mans delight be Love; but Womans delight be Pride
In Eden our Loves were the same here they are opposite
I have Loves of my own I will weave them in Albions Spectre
Cast thou in Jerusalems shadows thy Loves! silk of liquid
Rubies Jacinths Crysolites: issuing from thy Furnaces, While
Jerusalem divides thy care: while thou carest for Jerusalem
Know that I never will be thine: also thou hidest Vala
From her these fibres shoot to shut me in a Grave.
You are Albions Victim. he has set his Daughter in your path

l.note: Blake may have etched numbers, top right, on all the plates, but only a small percentage of them printed in Copy E. Here, a "[8?]8" in white line is partially visible just below the pen-and-ink numeral "88" of line 1.

lg.l: Los answerd sighing like the Bellows of his Furnaces
I care not! the swing of my Hammer shall measure the starry round
When in Eternity Man converses with Man they enter
Into each others Bosom (which are Universes of delight)
In mutual interchange. and first their Emanations meet
Surrounded by their Children, if they embrace & comingle
The Human Four-fold Forms mingle also in thunders of Intellect
But if the Emanations mingle not; with storms & agitations
Of earthquakes & consuming fires they roll apart in fear
For Man cannot unite with Man but by their Emanations
Which stand both Male & Female at the Gates of each Humanity
How then can I ever again be united as Man with Man
While thou my Emanation refusest my Fibres of dominion.
When Souls mingle & join thro all the Fibres of Brotherhood
Can there be any secret joy on Earth greater than this?
Enitharmon answerd: This is Womans World, nor need she any
Spectre to defend her from Man. I will Create secret places
And the masculine names of the places Merlin & Arthur.
A triple Female Tabernacle for Moral Law I weave
That he who loves Jesus may loathe terrified Female love
Till God himself become a Male subservient to the Female.
She spoke in scorn & jealousy alternate torments; and
So speaking she sat down on Sussex shore singing lulling
Cadences. & playing in sweet intoxication among the glistening
Fibres of Los: sending them over the Ocean eastward into
The realms of dark death; O perverse to thyself, contrarious
To thy own purposes; for when she began to weave
Shooting out in sweet pleasure her bosom in milky Love
Flowd into the aching fibres of Los, yet contending against him
In pride sendinding his Fibres over to her objects of jealousy"sendinding": i.e., "sending".
In the little lovely Allegoric Night of Albions Daughters
Which stretchd abroad expanding east & west & north & south
Thro' all the World of Erin & of Los & all their Children
A sullen smile broke from the Spectre in mockery & scorn
Knowing himself the author of their divisions & shrinkings, gratified
At their contentions, he wiped his tears he washd his visage.
The Man who respects Woman shall be despised by Woman
And deadly cunning & mean abjectness only, shall enjoy them
For I will make their places of joy & love, excrementitious
Continually building. continually destroying in Family feuds
While you are under the dominion of a jealous Female
Unpermanent for ever because of love & jealousy.
You shall want all the Minute Particulars of Life
Thus joyd the Spectre in the dusky fires of Los's Forge, eyeing
Enitharmon who at her shining Looms sings lulling cadences
While Los stood at his Anvil in wrath the victim of their love
And hate: dividing the Space of Love with brazen Compasses
In Golgonooza & in Udan-Adan & in Entuthon of Urizen
The blow of his Hammer is Justice. the swing of his Hammer Mercy
The force of Los's Hammer is eternal Forgiveness; but
His rage or his mildness were vain, she scatterd his love on the wind
Eastward into her own Center, creating the Female Womb
In mild Jerusalem around the Lamb of God. Loud howl
The Furnaces of Los! loud roll the Wheels of Enitharmon
The Four Zoa's in all their faded majesty burst out in fury
And fire. Jerusalem took the Cup which foamd in Vala's hand
Like the red Sun upon the mountains in the bloody day
Upon the Hermaphroditic Wine-presses of Love & Wrath.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The right-margin vignette shows a gowned, long-haired female (upper corner) giving to or receiving from a male(?) figure in tights an indeterminate object (perhaps a basket or disproportionally large crown). The male's left arm, only partially extended, is raised horizontally and appears to be handless (terminating in a spike). Below the lower figure, rooted in the bottom corner, a lithe tree or vine bears a few scanty leaves. Though typical of Blake's small-scale interlinear motifs, the birds clustering around the tree and the figure in tights seem integrated into the vignette. A cloudy blue sky backs the text, becoming more intense in the right margin, and a strip of earth(?) runs across the bottom of the plate.

component.illusobjdesc: The right-margin vignette shows a gowned, long-haired female (upper corner) giving to or receiving from a second figure an indeterminate object (perhaps a basket or a disproportionally large crown). The female faces down, but her upper body is twisted slightly counterclockwise, allowing her to look up over her shoulder. Her arms are extended vertically.

Midway down the right margin, a short-haired male(?) figure in tights gives to or receives from a second figure (above) an indeterminate object (perhaps a basket or disproportionally large crown). The male is seen from behind but looks up. His left leg is obscured from view, his right extended backward and slightly bent at the knee. He raises his left arm, only partially extended, horizontally; it appears to be handless (terminating in a spike instead), but is perhaps only ambiguously drawn or printed.
The two figures in the right margin appear to be exchanging an indeterminate object (opposite lines 20-24): perhaps a basket or disproportionally large crown.
Rooted in the bottom right corner of the plate, a lithe tree or vine grows up the margin, bearing a few scanty leaves. Root fragments line the side and top margins.

Though their small scale is typical of Blake's interlinear motifs, the numerous birds clustering in the vicinity of the lower figure and lithe tree in the right margin seem integrated into the vignette. They fly in pairs opposite lines 25, 35-36, and 38- 39, and in groups of three and four, respectively, opposite lines 45-48 and 59; stray marks near the right hand and calf of the lower figure resemble wing-like fragments.

Cloudy blue sky—its color more intense in the right margin and very dark in the top right corner—backs the designs and upper portions of text on the plate. A strip of earth(?) lines the bottom margin.

lg.l: Tho divided by the Cross & Nails & Thorns & Spear
In cruelties of Rahab & Tirzah permanent endure
A. terrible indefinite Hermaphroditic formIn Copy E, the period between "A" and "terrible" may be a stray dot of ink or a fragment of the "W" in the line below.
A Wine-press of Love & Wrath double Hermaphoditic"Hermaphoditic": i.e., "Hermaphroditic".
Twelvefold in Allegoric pomp in selfish holiness
The Pharisaion, the Grammateis. the Presbuterion.
The Archiereus, the Iereus, the Saddusaion, double
Each withoutside of the other, covering eastern heaven
Thus was the Covering Cherub reveald majestic image
Of Selfhood, Body put off. the Antichrist accursed
Coverd with precious stones. a Human Dragon terrible
And bright. stretchd over Europe & Asia gorgeous
In three nights he devourd the rejected. corse of death
His Head dark, deadly, in its Brain incloses a reflexion
Of Eden all perverted; Egypt on the Gihon many tongued
And many mouthd: Ethiopia. Lybia, the Sea of Rephaim
Minute Particulars in slavery I behold among the brick-kilns
Disorganizd, & there is Pharoh in his iron Court:
And the Dragon of the River & the Furnaces of iron.
Outwoven from Thames & Tweed & Severn awful streams
Twelve ridges of Stone frown over all the Earth in tyrant pride
Frown over each River stupendous Works of Albions Druid Sons
And Albions Forests of Oaks coverd the Earth from Pole to Pole
His Bosom wide reflects Moab & Ammon. on the River
Pison. since calld Arnon, there is Heshbon beautiful
The flocks of Rabbath on the Arnon & the Fish-pools of Heshbon
Whose currents flow into the Dead Sea by Sodom & Gomorra
Above his Head high arching Wings black filld with Eyes
Spring upon iron sinews from the Scapulæ & Os Humeri.
There Israel in bondage to his Generalizing Gods
Molech & Chemosh. & in his left breast is Philistea
In Druid Temples over the whole Earth with Victims Sacrifice,
From Gaza to Damascus Tyre & Sidon & the Gods
Of Javan thro the Isles of Grecia & all Europes Kings
Where Hiddekel pursues his course among the rocks
Two Wings spring from his ribs of brass. starry. black as night
But translucent their blackness as the dazling of gems
His Loins inclose Babylon on Euphrates beautiful
And Rome in sweet Hesperia, there Israel scatterd abroad
In martyrdoms & slavery I behold: ah vision of sorrow!
Inclosed by eyeless Wings, glowing with fire as the iron
Heated in the Smiths forge, but cold the wind of their dread fury
But in the midst of a devouring Stomach, Jerusalem
Hidden within the Covering Cherub as in a Tabernacle
Of threefold workmanship in allegoric delusion & woe
There the Seven Kings of Canaan & Five Baalim of Philistea
Sihon & Og the Anakim & Emim Nephilim & Gibborim
From Babylon to Rome & the Wings spread from Japan
Where the Red Sea terminates the World of Generation & Death
To Irelands farthest rocks where Giants builded their Causeway
Into the Sea of Rephaim, but the Sea oerwhelmd them all,
A Double Female now appeard within the Tabernacle,
Religion hid in War, a Dragon red & hidden Harlot
Each within other. but without a Warlike Mighty-one
Of dreadful power sitting upon Horeb pondering dire
And mighty preparations mustering multitudes innumerable
Of warlike sons among the sands of Midian & Aram
For multitudes of those who sleep in Alla descend
Lured by his warlike symphonies of tabret pipe & harp
Burst the bottoms of the Graves & Funeral Arks of Beulah
Wandering in that unknown Night beyond the silent Grave
They become One with the Antichrist & are absorbd in him

lg.l: The Feminine separates from the Masculine & both from Man.
Ceasing to be His Emanations, Life to Themselves assuming:
And while they circumscribe his Brain. & while they circumscribe
His Heart, & while they circumscribe his Loins! a Veil & Net
Of Veins of red Blood grows around them like a scarlet robe.
Covering them from the sight of Man like the woven Veil of Sleep
Such as the Flowers of Beulah weave to be their Funeral Mantles
But dark: opake: tender to touch, & painful: & agonizing
To the embrace of love, & to the mingling of soft fibres
Of tender affection. that no more the Masculine mingles
With the Feminine. but the Sublime is shut out from the Pathos
In howling torment, to build stone walls of separation, compelling
The Pathos, to weave curtains of hiding secresy from the torment.
Bowen & Conwenna stood on Skiddaw cutting the Fibres
Of Benjamin from Chesters River: loud the River; loud the Mersey
And the Ribble. thunder into the Irish sea, as the Twelve Sons
Of Albion drank & imbibed the Life & eternal Form of Luvah
Cheshire & Lancashire & Westmoreland groan in anguish
As they cut the fibres from the Rivers he sears them with hot
Iron of his Forge & fixes them into Bones of chalk & Rock
Conwenna sat above: with solemn cadences she drew
Fibres of life out from the Bones into her golden Loom
Hand had his Furnace on Highgates heights & it reachd
To Brockley Hills across the Thames! he with double Boadicea
In cruel pride cut Reuben apart from the Hills of Surrey
Comingling with Luvah & with the Sepulcher of Luvah
For the Male is a Furnace of beryll; the Female is a golden Loom
Los cries; No Individual ought to appropriate to Himself
Or to his Emanation. any of the Universal Characteristics
Of David or of Eve, of the Woman. or of the Lord.
Of Reuben or of Benjamin, of Joseph or Judah or Levi
Those who dare appropriate to themselves Universal Attributes
Are the Blasphemous Selfhoods & must be broken asunder
A Vegetated Christ & a Virgin Eve, are the Hermaphroditic
Blasphemy, by his Maternal Birth he is that Evil-One
And his Maternal Humanity must be put off Eternally
Lest the Sexual Generation swallow up Regeneration
Come Lord Jesus take on thee the Satanic Body of Holiness
So Los cried in the Valleys of Middlesex in the Spirit of Prophecy
While in Selfhood Hand & Hyle & Bowen & Skofeld appropriate
The Divine Names: seeking to Vegetate the Divine Vision
In a corporeal & ever dying Vegetation & Corruption
Mingling with Luvah in One. they become One Great Satan
Loud scream the Daughters of Albion beneath the Tongs & Hammer
Dolorous are their lamentations in the burning Forge
They drink Reuben & Benjamin as the iron drinks the fire
They are red hot with cruelty: raving along the Banks of Thames
And on Tyburns Brook among the howling Victims in loveliness
While Hand & Hyle condense the Little-ones & erect them into
A mighty Temple even to the stars: but they Vegetate
Beneath Los's Hammer, that Life may not be blotted out.
For Los said: When the Individual appropriates Universality
He divides into Male & Female: & when the Male & Female.
Appropriate Individuality, they become an Eternal Death.
Hermaphroditic worshippers of a God of cruelty & law!
Your Slaves & Captives; you compell to worship a God of Mercy.
These are the Demonstrations of Los. & the blows of my mighty Hammer
So Los spoke. And the Giants of Albion terrified & ashamed"and" was revised on the copperplate to "And".
With Los's thunderous Words, began to build trembling rocking Stones
For his Words roll in thunders & lightnings among the Temples
Terrified rocking to & fro upon the earth, & sometimes
Resting in a Circle in Malden or in Strathness or Dura,
Plotting to devour Albion & Los the friend of Albion
Denying in private; mocking God & Eternal Life: & in Public
Collusion, calling themselves Deists, Worshipping the Maternal
Humanity: calling it Nature. and Natural Religion
But still the thunder of Los peals loud & thus the thunders cry
These beautiful Witchcrafts of Albion, are gratifyd by Cruelty

illustration.illusobjdesc: The vignette at the bottom of the plate shows a nude male, probably Albion (cf. Plates 25, 45, and 85), reclining on a bed of grass, his head and upper body silhouetted against a blue sky. Lengths of entrails, which look vegetative in nature, emanate symmetrically from either side of his head and torso, and apparently from his left buttock and thigh, and spiral left and right where they run up against piles of organic debris in the margins of the design. Rooted in the center of the right spiral is an ear of grain(?); and superimposed over the spiral at left is a six-pointed Star of David, blazing like a fiery sun and seemingly turning in a counterclockwise direction (perhaps one of Albion's—or his sons'—Starry Wheels); the kernels of grain hanging in the right spiral appear to be reflected and magnified in the star's center.

component.illusobjdesc: The vignette at the bottom of the plate shows a nude male, probably Albion (cf. Plates 25, 45, and 85), reclining on a bed of grass; his head is severely bent back, and his posture is twisted, upper body supine, lower body oriented left, with legs drawn up. He props himself up on his right and (presumably) left arms and hands. Lengths of entrails, which look vine-like/vegetative in nature, emanate symmetrically from either side of his torso and head (suggesting fibrous hair), and apparently from his left buttock and thigh, spiraling left and right where they run up against piles of organic debris in the margins of the design.

Superimposed over the spiral at left is a six-pointed Star of David, blazing like a fiery sun and seemingly turning in a counterclockwise direction—perhaps one of Albion's (or Albion's sons') Starry Wheels (e.g., Plate 94, line 3; Plate 44, line 8; Plate 18, line 45; cf. the design on Plate 20, between lines 14 and 15). The kernels of grain(?) hanging in the right spiral appear to be reflected and magnified in the star's center.

What appears to be a compost of (mostly) dead leaves (but see the green leaf on top of the pile at left) and miscellaneous vegetation collects in each of the bottom corners of the design; a thin strip of the organic residue serves as a bridge between the piles, edging the bed of grass on which Albion reclines.
Blue sky backs the design at the bottom of the plate.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vines with spiky leaves line the right margin of the plate; patches of blue at lower right extend the sky motif of the major design, and there is the suggestion of clouds across the entire plate.

Traces of blue wash in the lower right margin extend the sky motif of the major design, and there is the suggestion of clouds across the entire plate.

l.note: Remaining letter fragments indicate that Blake deleted what was originally the first line of poetry on the plate. Erdman attempts to recover some of the deletions as follows (Erdman page 812n): "Forgiveness of Enemies ?can [ ] only [ ] God [ ]".

lg.l: It is easier to forgive an Enemy than to forgive a Friend:
The man who permits you to injure him, deserves your vengeance:
He also will recieve it: go Spectre! obey my most secret desire!
Which thou knowest without my speaking: Go to these Fiends of Righteousness
Tell them to obey their Humanities, & not pretend Holiness;
When they are murderers: as far as my Hammer & Anvil permit
Go, tell them that the Worship of God, is honouring his gifts
In other men: & loving the greatest men best. each according
To his Genius; which is the Holy Ghost in Man; there is no other
God, than that God who is the intellectual fountain of Humanity:
He who envies or calumniates: which is murder & cruelty,
Murders the Holy-one! Go tell them this & overthrow their cup,
Their bread, their altar-table, their incense & their oath:
Their marriage & their baptism, their burial & consecration:
I have tried to make friends by corporeal gifts but have only
Made enemies: I never made friends but by spiritual gifts;
By severe contentions of friendship & the burning fire of thought.
He who would see the Divinity must see him in his Children
One first, in friendship & love; then a Divine Family, & in the midst
Jesus will appear; so he who wishes to see a Vision; a perfect Whole
Must see it in its Minute Particulars; Organized & not as thou
O Fiend of Righteousness pretendest; thine is a Disorganized
And snowy cloud; brooder of tempests & destructive War
You smile with pomp & rigor: you talk of benevolence & virtue!
I act with benevolence & virtue & get murderd time after time:
You accumulate Particulars, & murder by analyzing, that you
May take the aggregate; & you call the aggregate Moral Law:
And you call that Swelld & bloated Form; a Minute Particular,
But General Forms have their vitality in Particulars: & every
Particular is a Man; a Divine Member of the Divine Jesus.
So Los cried at his Anvil in the horrible darkness weeping!
The Spectre builded stupendous Works, taking the Starry Heavens
Like to a curtain & folding them according to his will
Repeating the Smaragdine Table of Hermes to draw Los down
Into the Indefinite, refusing to believe without demonstration
Los reads the Stars of Albion! the Spectre reads the Voids
Between the Stars; among the arches of Albions Tomb sublime
Rolling the Sea in rocky paths! forming Leviathan
And Behemoth; the War by Sea enormous & the War
By Land astounding: erecting pillars in the deepest Hell.
To reach the heavenly arches; Los beheld undaunted furious
His heavd Hammer; he swung it round & at one blow,
In unpitying ruin driving down the pyramids of pride
Smiting the Spectre on his Anvil & the integuments of his Eye
And Ear unbinding in dire pain, with many blows,
Of strict severity self-subduing, & with many tears labouring.
Then he sent forth the Spectre all his pyramids were grains
Of sand & his pillars: dust on the flys wing: & his starry
Heavens; a moth of gold & silver mocking his anxious grasp
Thus Los alterd his Spectre & every Ratio of his Reason
He alterd time after time, with dire pain & many tears
Till he had completely divided him into a separate space.
Terrified Los sat to behold trembling & weeping & howling
I care not whether a Man is Good or Evil; all that I care
Is whether he is a Wise Man or a Fool, Go! put off Holiness
And put on Intellect: or my thundrous Hammer shall drive thee
To wrath which thou condemnest: till thou obey my voice
So Los terrified cries; trembling & weeping & howling! Beholding

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned female with long hair, apparently Jerusalem, sits on the ground, surrounded by the heads of four dead(?) males(?), perhaps the Four Zoas. All the heads face upwards, eyes closed; one, at Jerusalem's knee, is an old man with a long beard that stretches along the ground in front of her. She may be looking down toward him as she raises her arms upward from her bent elbows and holds her palms up. In the grassy background a hilly horizon is marked by three trilithons and one unidentifiable structure(?), perhaps a hill. In the sky right of the seated female, the word "Jerusalem" appears above two of the trilithons, perhaps naming simultaneously the city represented by the trilithons and the woman in the foreground. The sky is washed to suggest dawn breaking among dark clouds in a kind of halo above Jerusalem's head. In the lower right margin, below the bearded head, there are two worms. Along the lower right and bottom edges of the design are flames or leafless vegetation.

component.illusobjdesc: A female with long hair, apparently Jerusalem, sits on the ground in the midst of four heads. She wears a long gown whose folds fan out on the ground in front of the leftmost head. Her right leg is apparently drawn up under her and her bent left leg is extended backward. Her bare left foot is visible. Facing forward, her arms bent upward and hands raised with the palms up, she twists her body counterclockwise and bends her neck sharply right, perhaps to look down toward the bearded head at her left knee. A bright area of sky creates the effect of a halo about her head; in that respect she seems to represent the rising sun.

The heads of four dead(?) males(?) surround a female sitting on the grassy ground. All the heads face upwards, eyes closed. They may be the Four Zoas—Luvah, Tharmas, Urthona, and Urizen. (There are other, perhaps less probable, identifications, such as the four groups or nations named in line 2 of this plate or the four sons of Jerusalem named on Plate 71, lines 51-53.) The two heads furthest to the right are turned somewhat forward: of those two, the one in the background is also bent backward; the one in the foreground, at the woman's knee, an old man with a long beard that stretches along the ground in front of her, is most likely Urizen. The other three cannot be distinguished. The one left of the female may have short, curly hair.
In the lower right margin, below the bearded head, there are two worms with distinct reticulations. The worm to the left has a single coil. The worms may double as roots.

The scene is set in a landscape of grassy hills. Along the lower right and bottom edges of the design are flames or, more likely, leafless, spiky vegetation. The worm-like forms in the lower right margin may double as roots. There may be a tree (of indistinct shape) on the horizon at far right, beside the trilithons.

The sky is washed to suggest dawn breaking among dark clouds in a kind of halo above Jerusalem's head, with the suggestion perhaps of beams of light emanating from her head as well. In that respect she seems to represent the rising sun itself. The upper block of text is outlined in the shape of a cloud.

On the horizon there are three trilithons, one to the left of the sitting female and two to the right. They may of course represent Stonehenge but, considering the label "Jerusalem" above the two to the right, it seems likely that the trilithons represent the city (though the two may not be mutually exclusive in Blakean terms). There is a fourth unidentifiable shape on the horizon—just left of the two structures on the right. It may conceivably be the jagged stone that reappears on the left horizon of Plate 94 or it may be a hill in the distance.

"Jerusalem" appears in the sky above the two trilithons on the right, perhaps as a label for both the city and the female sitting in the center of the design. A break in the clouds doubles as an underscore for the word.

lg.l: What do I see! The Briton Saxon Roman Norman amalgamating
In my Furnaces into One Nation the English: & taking refuge
In the Loins of Albion. The Canaanite united with the fugitive
Hebrew. whom she divided into Twelve. & sold into Egypt
Then scatterd the Egyptian & Hebrew to the four Winds:
This sinful Nation Created in our Furnaces & Looms is Albion
So Los spoke. Enitharmon answerd in great terror in Lambeths Vale
The Poets Song draws to its period & Enitharmon is no more.
For if he be that Albion I can never weave him in my Looms
But when he touches the first fibrous thread. like filmy dew
Jerusalem
My Looms will be no more & I annihilate vanish for ever
Then thou wilt Create another Female according to thy Will.
Los answerd swift as the shuttle of gold. Sexes must vanish & cease
To be. when Albion arises from his dread repose O lovely Enitharmon:
When all their Crimes. their Punishments their Accusations of Sin:
All their Jealousies Revenges. Murders. hidings of Cruelty in Deceit
Appear only in the Outward Spheres of Visionary Space and Time.
In the shadows of Possibility by Mutual Forgiveness forevermore
And in the Vision & in the Prophecy. that we may Foresee & Avoid
The terrors of Creation & Redemption & Judgment. Beholding them
Displayd in the Emanative Visions of Canaan in Jerusalem & in Shiloh
And in the Shadows of Remembrance. & in the Chaos of the Spectre
Amalek. Edom. Egypt. Moab. Ammon. Ashur. Philistea. around Jerusalem
Where the Druids reard their Rocky Circles to make permanent Remembrance
Of Sin. & the Tree of Good & Evil sprang from the Rocky Circle & Snake
Of the Druid. along the Valley of Rephaim from Camberwell to Golgotha
And framed the Mundane Shell Cavernous in Length Bedth & HighthIn Copy E, the "r" in "Bredth" did not print.

objnote.p: The coloring in Copy E somewhat obscures the text on the nude bodies of the figures at the top of the plate.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The fiery upper and lower designs of the plate are integrated by the flames licking the spaces at the ends of lines in the intervening text panel. In the flames, three male figures at the top of the plate kneel in a queue on their left knees and bend forward, their right feet planted squarely on the ground (only the outlines of the rear figures are discernible, but the threesome clearly mirror one another in posture). They face right, differing only in the orientation of their heads. Their arms are extended in front of them, the right raised higher than the left to point directly ahead at some indeterminate object in the wings or on another plate; the left index fingers point down, perhaps in a denunciatory gesture. They are identified by the inscription on their bodies, clearer in monochrome copies, whose tripartite subject is distributed across their backs (from back to front), and whose predicate and closing comparative clause are written on the front and middle figures' buttocks and thighs: "Anytus / Melitus / & Lycon / thought Socrates / a very Pernicious / Man / So Caiphus / thought Jesus". Anytus, Melitus, and Lycon are the three men whose accusations resulted in Socrates's execution, and Caiaphus is the high priest who played a role in Jesus's death, but the iconography and language simultaneously relate the three figures to the brothers Leigh, John, and Robert Hunt: their journal, The Examiner, used as its insignia a pointing hand, and an 1809 issue maligned Blake and his exhibition in a review that claimed the artist's putative mental instability had reached "a pernicious height." Together the three pointing figures may represent the character Hand. At the bottom of the plate a nude, long-haired female engulfed in fire reclines on her left side. In front of her is an indeterminate structure, perhaps a low wall. Alternatively, it could represent the side of a small boat, a possibility consistent with the wave-like appearance of the flames that lap across the bottom margin. The figure may be Enitharmon, who "rais[es] her head" in line 10. The wash across the text panel suggests firelight.

component.illusobjdesc: At the top of the plate, three nude males with short and curly hair bend forward and kneel in a row on their left knees (or else lunge deeply), their right feet planted squarely on the ground. (Only the outlines of the rear figures are discernible, but the threesome clearly mirror one another in posture.) The row is arranged on a diagonal axis from front center to back left. The figures' bodies partially overlap or coincide. They face right, differing only in the orientation of their heads (from back to front, they look forward, right, and away from the viewer). Their arms are extended in front of them, the right raised higher than the left to point directly ahead at some indeterminate object in the wings or on another plate; their left index fingers point down, perhaps in a denunciatory gesture. They are identified by the inscription on their bodies, clearer in monochrome copies, whose tripartite subject is distributed across their backs (from back to front), and whose predicate and closing comparative clause are written on the front and middle figures' buttocks and thighs: "Anytus / Melitus / & Lycon / thought Socrates / a very Pernicious / Man / So Caiphus / thought Jesus". Anytus, Melitus, and Lycon are the three men whose accusations resulted in Socrates's execution, and Caiaphus is the high priest who played a role in Jesus's death, but the iconography and inscription simultaneously relate the figures to the brothers Leigh, John, and Robert Hunt: their journal, The Examiner, used as its editorial insignia a pointing hand, and an 1809 issue maligned Blake and his exhibition of the same year in a review that claimed the artist's putative mental instability (and, by association, that of his admirers) had reached "a pernicious height."

The three men at the top of the plate are identified by the inscription on their bodies, clearer in monochrome copies, whose tripartite subject is distributed across their backs (from back to front), and whose predicate and closing comparative clause are written on the front and middle figures' buttocks and thighs: "Anytus / Melitus / & Lycon / thought Socrates / a very Pernicious / Man / So Caiphus / thought Jesus".

The fiery upper and lower designs of the plate are integrated by the smoky flames following the ends of lines in the intervening text panel (the tongue of fire licking the spaces opposite lines 23-26 is particularly prominent, while that immediately above it—right of lines 20-22—branches in root-like fashion). The flames engulfing the three figures at the top of the plate are smokier at the edges; those at the bottom are brightest and most intense around the nude female. The fire seems to lap across the bottom margin like waves. The wash across the text panel suggests firelight.

At the bottom of the plate a nude, long-haired female reclines on her left side, her arms at her side; presumably the left arm is braced to support the weight of her upper body, though this is ambiguously represented. She faces forward but looks up with a sad and/or placid countenance, perhaps at the figures above her. The flames surrounding her provide an aura effect. She may be Enitharmon, who "rais[es] her head" in line 10.

In front of the nude female at the bottom of the plate is an indeterminate structure, perhaps a low wall. Alternatively, it could represent the side of a small boat, a possibility consistent with the wave-like appearance of the flames that lap across the bottom margin.

lg.l: O Rintrah! O Palamabron! What are your dire & awful purposes
Enitharmons name is nothing before you: you forget all my Love!
The Mothers love of obedience is forgotten & you seek a Love
Of the pride of dominion. that wilt Divorce Ocalythron & Elynittria
Upon East Moor in Derbyshire & along the Valleys of Cheviot
Could you Love me Rintrah, if you Pride not in my Love
As Reuben found Mandrakes in the field & gave them to his Mother
Pride meets with Pride upon the Mountains in the stormy day
In that terrible Day of Rintrahs Plow & of Satans driving the Team.
Ah! then I heard my little ones weeping along the Valley:
Ah! then I saw my beloved ones fleeing from my Tent
Merlin was like thee Rintrah among the Giants of Albion
Judah was like Palamabron: O Simeon! O Levi! ye fled away
How can I hear my little ones weeping along the Valley
Or how upon the distant Hills see my beloveds Tents.
Then Los again took up his speech as Enitharmon ceast
Fear not my Sons this Waking Death, he is become One with me
Behold him here! We shall not Die! we shall be united in Jesus.
Will you suffer this Satan this Body of Doubt that Seems but Is Not
To occupy the very threshold of Eternal Life. if Bacon. Newton. Locke
Deny a Conscience in Man & the Communion of Saints & Angels
Contemning the Divine Vision & Fruition. Worshiping the Deus
Of the Heathen. The God of This World. & the Goddess Nature
Mystery Babylon the Great. The Druid Dragon & hidden Harlot
Is it not that Signal of the Morning which was told us in the Beginning
Thus they converse upon Mam-Tor. the Graves thunder under their feet

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the top of the plate, three muscular nude male figures may represent an event that follows the one depicted at the top of the previous plate: the three accusers shown in action there have now fallen. The foremost figure, with short curly hair, is lying on his left side, his upper body raised, its weight resting on his braced left arm. His body is twisted to face forward; his head is bent sharply back; his legs are crossed. Only the upward-facing head of the second, middle figure is visible at the far right. The rear figure seems to be lying on his side, turned away from the viewer, but with his head, again, facing up and bent back. From the figures extend several thick lines very much like those on (for example) the figure at the bottom of Plate 74: fibres of vegetative generation. Behind the figures is a patch of blue sky; at its periphery are clouds or a continuation of the sky at sunrise from the lower design. There is evidence of grass on the ground left and right of the figures.

Together they may represent the character Hand (see the description of Plate 93). The foremost figure, with short, curly hair, is lying on his left side, his upper body raised, its weight resting on his braced left arm. His body is twisted to face forward; his head is bent sharply back. His legs are together, with the top (right) leg bent slightly forward of the lower leg, and the foot of the right is crossed in front of the left, which extends upward in a shallow arc. Only the upward-facing head and part of the right shoulder of the second, middle figure is visible at the far right. The rear figure seems to be lying on his side, turned away from the viewer, but with his head, again, facing up and bent back. Upward and left from the feet, legs, and torsos of the figures extend several thick lines very much like those on (for example) the figure at the bottom of Plate 74: fibres of vegetative generation, intestines perhaps, or (more generally) streams of gore.

Behind the figures is a patch of blue sky; at its periphery are what may be clouds or a continuation of the sky at sunrise (or sunset) from the lower design.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text on the plate suggests that the figures in the lower design may be "Albion cold" (line 2), supine beneath "England a Female Shadow" who "lays upon his bosom heavy" (lines 8-9)—or, a few lines later, "England who is Brittannia" who "awoke from Death on Albions bosom" (line 21). In the design, at least, she shows no sign of waking. She wears a long gown, and her long hair streams forward along her left arm, which reaches out as if embracing him. Albion is depicted as a gowned old man, with long hair and the suggestion of a beard, lying flat on his back. Between his body and the grassy ground is some kind of cloth, perhaps part of his own garment. The lighting of the lower design suggests a sunrise over a dark, slightly hilly landscape. A jagged rock juts out of the ground at upper left. (Compare the less identifiable mass in Plate 92—on the horizon between the seated female and the two trilithons on the right.) The rock may represent London Stone (line 25), though so may the solid rectangular object at far right. The stone structures on the horizon suggest that the location is the same as that of Plate 92—Jerusalem. To the right of the rising sun is one trilithon and what appears to be a solid rectangular stone, perhaps an altar.

component.illusobjdesc: The text on the plate suggests that the supine figure in the lower design may be "Albion cold" (line 2) and that the prone figure draped over him is "England a Female Shadow" who "lays upon his bosom heavy" (lines 8-9)—or, a few lines later, "England who is Brittannia" who "awoke from Death on Albions bosom" (line 21). In the design, at least, she shows no sign of waking. She wears a long gown, and her long hair streams forward along her left arm, which reaches out as if embracing him. Though the exact position of her body is ambiguous, her lower body seems to be favoring its left side while the upper body is slightly twisted counterclockwise to lie flat across the chest of Albion. Her legs are crossed and her right foot is visible.

The text on the plate suggests that the supine figure in the lower design may be "Albion cold" (line 2) and that the prone figure draped over him is "England a Female Shadow" who "lays upon his bosom heavy" (lines 8-9). If so, Albion is depicted as a gowned old man with long hair and the suggestion of a beard. He lies flat on his back, his head to the left, with his only visible arm straight by his side. Both feet are visible. Between his body and the ground is some kind of cloth, perhaps the loose cloth of his garment (depicted as ample on Plate 96) or a separate item—the text describes him as swathed in "weeds of Death" and "thick cloud" (lines 6, 10- 11).
Coloring in the background and middle distance suggests grass. Lines in the near foreground and the left middle distance suggest long grass lying flat or some sort of spiky vegetation.

Between the supine figure's body and the ground is some kind of cloth, perhaps the loose cloth of his garment (ample as depicted on Plate 96) or a separate item, such as a blanket or some kind of bedding; the text describes him as swathed in "weeds of Death" and "thick cloud" in lines 6 and 10-11. The details of the depiction are a bit improbable: lines at the feet suggest that the cloth comes up between Albion's legs.

The lighting of the lower design suggests a sunrise (or sunset) over a dark landscape, the horizon slightly rounded. Beams of light emanate from the center of the horizon line. A jagged, approximately triangular rock juts out of the ground at upper left. (Compare the less identifiable mass in Plate 92—on the horizon between the seated female and the two trilithons on the right.) The rock may represent London Stone (line 25), though so may the solid rectangular object at far right. It could conceivably be intended to recall biblical mountains, though of course the scale is not realistic.

The stone structures on the horizon suggest that the location is the same as that of Plate 92—Jerusalem, with overtones of Stonehenge and London Stone (lines 25-26), though that "druid" monument, often mentioned in the text, may be represented by the jagged rock further left. To the right of the rising (or setting) sun is one trilithon and what appears to be a solid rectangular stone, perhaps an altar.

lg.l: Albion cold lays on his Rock: storms & snows beat round him
Beneath the Furnaces & the starry Wheels & the Immortal Tomb
Howling winds cover him: roaring seas dash furious against him
In the deep darkness broad lightnings glare long thunders roll
The weeds of Death inwrap his hands & feet blown incessant
And washd incessant by the for-ever restless sea-waves foaming abroad
Upon the white Rock. England a Female Shadow as deadly damps
Of the Mines of Cornwall & Derbyshire lays upon his bosom heavy
Moved by the wind in volumes of thick cloud returning folding round
His loins & bosom unremovable by swelling storms & loud rending
Of enraged thunders. Around them the Starry Wheels of their Giant Sons
Revolve: & over them the Furnaces of Los & the Immortal Tomb around
Erin sitting in the Tomb. to watch them unceasing night and day
And the Body of Albion was closed apart from all Nations.
Over them the famishd Eagle screams on boney Wings and around
Them howls the Wolf of famine deep heaves the Ocean black thundering
Around the wormy Garments of Albion: then pausing in deathlike silence
Time was Finished! The Breath Divine Breathed over Albion
Beneath the Furnaces & starry Wheels and in the Immortal Tomb
And England who is Brittannia awoke from Death on Albions bosom
She awoke pale & cold she fainted seven times on the Body of Albion
O pitious Sleep O pitious Dream! O God O God awake I have slain
In Dreams of Chastitity & Moral Law I have Murdered Albion! Ah!"Chastitity": i.e., "Chastity".
In Stone-henge & on London Stone & in the Oak Groves of Malden
I have Slain him in my Sleep with the Knife of the Druid O England
O all ye Nations of the Earth behold ye the Jealous Wife

The Eagle & the Wolf & Monkey & Owl & the King & Priest were thereAccording to Erdman, Blake first etched the text that is now on Plate 94 on the top half of what is now Plate 95, subsequently deleted the text from Plate 95 and etched it on Plate 94, adding, in the process, this line (Erdman page 812n).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The central design shows Albion rising at last from his long slumber. Seen from behind but facing right and up, he lunges into "the wrath of God breaking bright flaming on all sides around / His awful limbs" (lines 7-8); he is nude except for the flesh-like drapery cascading from his buttocks. His right arm is raised at 135 degrees, with palm up; his left bent at the elbow, hand planted squarely on a slab of rock. Beneath him is the ghostly shape of his former self (before Brittannia rouses him from his "deadly / Sleep" [Plate 96, lines 22-23]). This supine Albion, bearded and apparently older, with eyes closed, resembles the figure on the previous plate: earlier the figure was deleted incompletely from the metal and then restored through coloring in this copy.

component.illusobjdesc: The central design shows Albion rising at last from his long slumber. Seen from behind but facing right and up, he lunges into "the wrath of God breaking bright flaming on all sides around / His awful limbs" (lines 7-8); only the toes of his right foot make contact with the surface beneath him. He is nude except for the flesh-like drapery cascading from his buttocks—perhaps the remnants of the "weeds of Death" or "thick cloud" that swathe him on Plate 94 (lines 6, 10-11; cf. the cloth between his body and the ground in the design on the bottom of Plate 94). His right arm is raised at 135 degrees, with palm up; his left bent at the elbow and drawn back, hand planted squarely behind him on a slab of rock. Albion's mouth is open, and his hair is short and curly.

Beneath the rising Albion is the ghostly shape of his former self (before Brittannia rouses him from his "deadly / Sleep" [Plate 96, lines 22-23]). This supine Albion, bearded and apparently older, with eyes closed, resembles the figure on the previous plate: earlier the figure was deleted incompletely from the metal and then restored through coloring in this copy, thus reinforcing the climactic resurrection of Albion. The figure's legs and feet appear to be engulfed in fire.
Albion's left hand is planted squarely on a slab of stone.

Albion lunges into a wall of white-hot fire (smoky at the edges), the visual flames reinforcing the textual (see lines 7-10, wherein clothes, lightning, and the wrath of God are all ablaze). The legs and feet of the sleeping version of his former self appear bathed in flames.
